PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is tomorrow's cultural statement intended to demonstrate the government's commitment to artists around Australia, many of whom are below the poverty line? If yes, does the government support today's announcement by the Australia Council of more than $2 million worth of grants to 11 elite artists, nine of whom reside in New South Wales and the other two in the Australian Capital Territory? In other words, not one red cent will go to any artist who does not live in the same state or territory as the Prime Minister.

—It is a pretty new theory of artistic merit that it is somehow geographically based. If Senator Alston cannot understand the difference between this kind of system and what it is designed to encourage and promote and some sort of strange, peculiar, perverse notion of equality of opportunity which he apparently wants to pursue, which is utterly out of kilter with the approach he adopts on these principles in every other context, he will not have too persuasive a story to sell. As I understand it, what these particular grants are about is to encourage the development of artistic excellence in the various areas which they are designed to pursue. Under those circumstances, judgments are made on that basis, and that basis alone.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from that that the minister is perfectly content to endorse an outcome that basically says to the rest of Australia, `You haven't got any artists in any discipline who are good enough to get one of these elite handouts.' Perhaps the minister would like to explain what he understands to be the rationale and at the same time tell us why the government has been prepared to spend more than $10 million on these sorts of handouts to people who have already made it, who are already at the top of their own professions, without the need for any government handouts at all, when there are thousands of struggling artists around Australia who desperately need some assistance in order to enable them to emerge and come through. Why does he support this sort of very elitist concept?

—The rationale for this particular program has been amply stated on innumerable occasions in the past by the Prime Minister. There is nothing new about these awards. Unlike many awards designed to encourage young artists, these are specifically designed to encourage and support people in mid-career, with an established track record in their particular artistic discipline—people whose income is very often very much less than Senator Alston might believe it is; certainly very much less than the income which he enjoys, even sitting where he is on the back bench, where he will permanently remain so far as his income is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is sitting on the front bench—it does not make any difference to his income; it only makes a difference if one is on this side of the chamber. He had better start planning another loan for the few years ahead because he will be there for a long while yet.

PARA.TAB: These awards are designed to give further encouragement to and the further capability for people with an established track record—and, in most instances, an international reputation—to take their career another stage forward and to contribute in ways which we know they are capable of. That is the rationale. If those opposite had any sort of track record when it came to genuinely supporting the arts, not least those who are young and struggling, through the education system or anywhere else, Senator Alston might be a little more credible than he is at the moment, because he totally lacks it right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Trade. My question is prompted by the report of the APEC Pacific Business Forum which was released on Saturday. This report sets out a number of ambitious recommendations for trade and investment liberalisation among APEC economies, including a recommendation for an earlier timetable for free trade to be adopted at the leaders' meeting in November. I ask: what is the significance of these recommendations for the APEC agenda and specifically for the APEC leaders' meeting next month?

—It was a very important report which the APEC Pacific Business Forum presented to President Suharto on Saturday and which is now public in Australia. It is a ringing endorsement from the APEC business community for the objective of free trade in APEC by a meaningful date early in the next century. This is the direction that Australia very much wants to see APEC move in and, more importantly, it is the direction in which President Suharto, in his capacity as chair of APEC for this year, has made clear he wishes to see the organisation going.

PARA.TAB: This report complements the report by the EPG which has already been discussed here in the Senate. As Senator Colston implies in his question, it sets the scene for an historic outcome from the APEC leaders' meeting in Bogor, an outcome which, if achieved, would contribute significantly to raising living standards in the region and providing a stable and certain future in the region.

The major recommendation of the Pacific Business Forum report calls on APEC leaders to launch a process leading to free trade in the region by the year 2010, which is even more ambitious than EPG—in fact, very ambitious. But the significant thing to note is that the recommendation was adopted unanimously by business representatives in the forum from every APEC economy. There has been some debate about this country or that economy, and whether the people support this ambitious objective, but business representatives from every economy that is a member of APEC unanimously endorsed these recommendations.

It will go to the leaders' meeting in Bogor. It springs from the commitment from the Blake Island summit, and it is, I think, important as a way of maintaining pressure on governments to keep abreast of the rapidly changing commercial environment in the APEC region. We sometimes think we are setting very ambitious agendas, but the business reality sometimes passes what we think is ambitious and sets an even faster pace.

The Australian government very much welcomes the report of the Pacific Business Forum. It is a valuable document to contribute to the discussion by APEC leaders at Bogor. It will provide a very strong commercial underpinning for those deliberations. It also has a range of very useful ideas it has drawn to help shape APEC's future beyond the question of trade and investment liberalisation.

One idea I want to draw the attention of the Senate to briefly is the proposal to call for leaders in Bogor to make a commitment to an immediate standstill on all new measures which obstruct trade amongst APEC economies. If the leaders were to commit to such a standstill—and it is not a simple concept; it needs a lot of discussion and consideration about its final form—it would provide an immediate and practical reassurance to the APEC business community of the stability and predictability of the trade and investment environment in which they operate.

The report shows a significant convergence of views within the region. It is encouraging for Australia because it is a convergence consistent with the direction in which we would like to see APEC go. I think we recognise the very important contribution business can make to APEC, and APEC will be successful only if it improves the environment for business people so that they can combine to enhance living standards in the region. So this is a very welcome report. It has potential to do a lot for people living throughout the region. On behalf of the Australian government, I would like to thank Australia's representatives on that APEC Pacific Business Forum, Imelda Roche and Philip Brass, for their outstanding contribution on this very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the reported disagreement between the government and its advisers in relation to the government's budget deficit strategy and I ask: is it not a fact that an increase in official interest rates, and therefore home mortgage rates, is inevitable between now and Christmas? Is it not a fact that impending mortgage rate increases could have been avoided if the government had brought down a much lower budget deficit for this financial year? Is it not a fact that the Governor of the Reserve Bank and the Secretary to the Treasury have been urging either a further lowering of the deficit or higher interest rates for a number of months now?

—The answer to the first question is no; to the second question, no; and, to the third question, I have not seen their advice but I know that from time to time advisers to the government give opinions as to what the level of the macro-economic setting should be. Of course, the government makes decisions taking on board their views and the other obligations that a government has to the wider community. That is what we did in the last budget, and that budget has proved to be an appropriate and a fitting one for Australia, and I think we are seeing the results of that on all fronts.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the inevitable interest rate rises occur will the government agree to make public the minutes of the meetings of the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer, as is now done in the United Kingdom and in the United States, so that Australians will be in a position to judge the extent to which the government accepts independent advice and the extent to which it allows political considerations to drive interest rates?
—Some weeks back—just over a month or so ago now—the variable home lending rate was adjusted.
—It went up.

—It went up by three-quarters of one per cent. The reason why that change was made is that the government is in a position of managing a strong recovery in this economy. In order to do so, one has to balance the pressures that could have led to higher inflation and higher costs against all the other pressures in the economy. At the time the adjustment was made it was hailed universally by all the economic commentators as a responsible and appropriate adjustment. I do not have to apologise to anyone—I certainly do not have to answer Senator Gibson's question in any apologetic manner, and I will not—because we are in the business of managing an economy which on all sides we can clearly see has been successful. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I am aware that the minister opened Australia's investment office in Singapore last week. Could the minister advise why Singapore was chosen as the location for this office and what are the objectives both for the office and the government's investment promotion program in general?

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for his question. Last Wednesday I had the pleasure of opening an investment office in Singapore—an investment office which will fall under the umbrella of Austrade, but which nonetheless will provide not only for Australians seeking information about investment in Singapore but also, in the wider ASEAN area, a means for that information to be funnelled back to Australia. Importantly, the office will allow investors in Singapore and in the wider ASEAN area who are seeking investment opportunities in Australia to be informed about the strength of the Australian economy and the growth in investment prospects in this part of the world. It will underpin this government's strategy on two-way investment which will bind Australia and the region more closely together.

PARA.TAB: The person to head up this office is Mr Mark See, a Singaporean by birth, who has had long experience in merchant banking throughout South-East Asia. He has latterly been an academic lecturing on international financial relations at Murdoch University in Western Australia. He is ideally suited to carry out the role that this office will require of him and be the person who will bind together investment intentions within the region.

Singapore is an important point for Australia to establish a high-profile position for an investment officer to attract investment to the region. Singaporean investment has been flowing into Australia. However, it has been related too narrowly, in my view, to real estate and housing, with some investment in resort and tourism. But I do think there are signs—and, indeed, during my short stay in Singapore, there were a number of interesting overtures made—of potential investment across a wider base in Australia in the manufacturing sector and in the services sector.

The government's white paper, Working Nation, set up a series of investment posts throughout the world so that Australia's economic profile as a source of high-level investment could be raised and begin to attract that investment from overseas and so that Australian investors could have access to overseas markets. We have put in place a number of other investment offices and, in addition to Singapore, we have posts in Hong Kong and New York. Others will be opened in the region shortly. In addition to that, the former Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, acts as a special investment representative for this nation and has been recently doing high-level work in Europe and in the United States which performs for us an essential link in bringing together investment opportunities with investment prospects here.

In 1993 the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed that Singapore had a stock of investment in Australia worth $6 billion and that our investment in Singapore was around $2 billion. With the opening of this new office, both those relationships are set to get better.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister Crean said on national television yesterday that any further savings on unemployment programs should be spent on reducing the deficit, rather than helping the 830,000 unemployed Australians. I ask: is it not enough that this government has chosen to reduce spending on employment-related programs by $3 billion in real terms over the next three years? Is that not enough of a contribution from the unemployed? Why is the government unwilling to take heed of Vince FitzGerald's call to look at both the expenditure and revenue sides of the budget? Is Minister Crean really saying that the unemployed should be the focus of the deficit reduction strategy of this government?

—In the two questions fired at me in this question time—one from the opposition and now one from the Democrats—I can say that we have both perspectives on the economic debate in Australia. I thank both honourable senators for their advice, but the government will nonetheless manage the economy as it has been doing quite successfully. There is no intention of doing anything other than providing a stable and sustainable future for jobs growth in this country.

PARA.TAB: In the Working Nation statement, which we released in May of this year, the government committed for expenditure something like $10 billion over the next four years to provide long-term unemployed people with re-entry to the labour force and with a possibility of their obtaining longer and more sustainable employment. It is and will remain a successful policy. As a policy goes, it is probably one of the leading policies in the Western world to deal with the intractable problem of the longer term unemployed and, as a Labor government, we make no apologies for spending that extra money to create that employment opportunity and to promote job growth.

One can see by resorting to statistics in the most recent publications of jobs growth in Australia that the economy is recovering, that jobs growth is growing quite strongly and that the policies we have set in train are working. In that context, I understand that Mr Crean was invited to answer a question on television about the deficit. He expressed a view which, I might say, is reasonably widely held in government. It is a view that, as I understand what he said, he will express and act on in the proper forums of government. There is no possibility, as the opposition keeps raising, of there being some sort of interim budget or other refocusing of the economy. We will deal with those issues in the forthcoming budget. I understand those are entirely the comments that Mr Crean made, which are consistent with the comments that have been made by the Treasurer.
So, to answer these questions in reverse order: we are taking advice of Vince FitzGerald's report. We are looking at both sides of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are taking a long time!

—We are, because that report was about national savings and any reduction in the budget deficit would contribute to the growth in national savings and the growth of investment capital in Australia for Australian industry. That is one of the things, I am sure, that Mr Crean had in mind. We are not asking the unemployed to contribute because, as I said, the program that we introduced in Working Nation is, in terms of outlays, a $10 billion boost to employment programs in this country over the next four years. Therefore, the opposition and the Democrats should simply stop trying to poke holes in what is a strong economy creating more employment for Australians. Rather, they should get behind the move to increase economic growth and spread the advantages more widely in the community.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the minister inform the Senate what effect the Australian government considers the kidnapping and subsequent murder of an Israeli soldier by Hamas militants will have on the future of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process?

—Australia condemns terrorism in whatever form it occurs. We are appalled at the kidnapping and murder of the young Israeli soldier, Corporal Waxman, by members of Izzedine al-Qassam, the military wing of the Islamic extremist group Hamas. The murder of Corporal Waxman, which was carried out in cold blood by his captors, is a repugnant act which I know will receive the unreserved condemnation of everyone in this chamber not only because of its cowardly and criminal nature but also because it was, of course, deliberately aimed at reversing the remarkable advances towards peace which have been achieved by Israeli and PLO representatives at the negotiating table.

PARA.TAB: We can well understand that emotions are running very high in Israel in the wake of what has happened but it is all the more encouraging that in these circumstances the Israeli government has committed itself to resuming negotiations with the PLO. Those who would seek to destroy the peace process must not be permitted to achieve their aims through acts of violence designed to break down the spirit of moderation and compromise. The peace process obviously remains the only means of guaranteeing a secure, prosperous and fair environment for all the people of the Middle East—one in which we hope all terrorist incidents will be a thing of the past.

It should be said very clearly that the PLO bears no responsibility whatsoever, clearly, for this tragic episode. The victim was kidnapped on Israeli territory and held in a West Bank town well outside the jurisdiction of the Palestinian Authority at all stages. Of course, the more that the PLO can do to discourage extremist elements from performing acts of violence against Israeli targets the better for the peace process; but it is clear that the PLO cannot be held accountable for elements outside its ranks and influence.

Might I just say, finally, that while we can well understand that under these current circumstances Mr Rabin has been very reluctant to celebrate the announcement of the Nobel Peace Prize, which he is sharing with Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Yasser Arafat, it should be said in this place that the award is an entirely appropriate recognition of the vision and the commitment to peace which these three leaders have demonstrated, and I am sure all Australians will join with me in sincerely congratulating those three recipients.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I ask: was the minister's failure to re-appoint the highly qualified, highly regarded and long experienced senior member of the Immigration Review Tribunal in Victoria, Mr Michael Clothier, to any membership position on the IRT based on a recommendation to this effect from the minister's assessment panel? If, on the other hand, the panel in fact recommended his appointment, what were the minister's reasons for rejecting the recommendation?

—The panel recommended that the other person, Michelle Scott, was much preferred as senior member. In those circumstances, it was up to me to determine whether Mr Clothier would then be asked to work under a new senior member, someone who had taken his position. In those circumstances, it is always difficult. I have known organisations that have had enormous structural problems because of previous and new heads working within them. In those circumstances, I determined that I would not proceed with an appointment for Mr Clothier in a position as a member of the tribunal.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister will recall that last week I asked several questions on his appointments, reappointments and non-reappointments to the IRT, including a request for advice as to which appointments were made either against or without the recommendation of the advisory panel, and which panel recommendations for appointment or reappointment he rejected. The minister took these questions on notice. He has not yet responded. I ask him now whether he will he do so as a matter of urgency in view of the urgent need to restore the confidence in this important body that his blatant abuse of ministerial office has shattered.

—I will do so. In saying that, let me say also that Senator Short talks about some aspersions on this body. In the last two or three weeks, we have seen a singling out of individuals, one after one, with all sorts of accusations and allegations. When we have asked for information to substantiate those allegations, there has been none forthcoming. What I have done this time is what I did with the Refugee Review Tribunal. I have appointed talented people from diverse backgrounds to work in this area. I will give Senator Short his answer in full. I am working on it, and it will not be all that long before he gets it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. With regard to the answer to the question I asked the minister last week about the imminent logging of Kerr block in the south-west of Western Australia and the responsibility of federal ministers to ensure that their actions do not threaten with extinction or significantly impede the recovery of endangered species such as the chuditch, I ask: is the minister aware that logging of Kerr block is to start in the next two weeks? What use is the endangered species clause on woodchip licences when the implication from the minister's answer to me is that the current scientific data on which the recovery plan for the chuditch is based is totally inadequate? What action will the minister take in light of the fact that he cannot be sure that the logging of Kerr block will not threaten with extinction or significantly impede the recovery of the chuditch?

—I have been informed that logging operations are due to commence in the Kerr block. My department is currently investigating the condition of the Kerr block and also adjacent forest blocks in order to determine the likely consequences of any logging operations there on the recovery of the chuditch. I will report back to Senator Chamarette on the outcomes of that investigation in the near future. It is a condition of the 1994 woodchip export licences that the exporter ensures that operations approved under the licence do not endanger or threaten species. This condition allows the Minister for Resources to reconsider the impact of approved operations on an endangered species should he believe that a species is threatened by activities that are authorised in the export licence.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. In relation to his seeking advice from the Australian Nature Conservation Agency on areas critical to the protection of the chuditch, as he mentioned earlier, how do the minister's actions match with the precautionary principle, as outlined in the Rio declaration on environment and development, when the Kerr block will have been logged by the time he forwards his advice to the Minister for Resources? Hopefully, he can give me some guarantee that he can provide this information prior to the logging that will commence in the next two weeks.

—The precautionary principle as outlined in the intergovernmental agreement on the environment is an important one, and it certainly does govern the way that I approach my responsibilities as minister for the environment in this and other matters. I can assure Senator Chamarette that I will be continuing to approach my responsibilities ensuring that threatened and endangered species are protected in any logging operations that might be proposed.

—Welcome back, Mr President. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and involves a matter of principle relating to ministerial declarations of interest. As ministers are required under cabinet rules to report to the Prime Minister the amount of assets or liabilities they acquire to ensure there is no potential for unrevealed conflicts of interest, does he support the principle that, because Mr Keating can report only to himself about any such acquisitions, he should not enter into any new significant risk taking commercial venture while in office? As Mr Keating's decision to purchase a $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra is, according to the minister, in order to lease it out and receive a tax benefit, so exposing himself to a large commercial risk exceeding $1 million, I ask: what checks, if any, are in place to ensure Mr Keating reports any potential conflict of interest that may emerge from his business activities? To whom does he report, or is he not answerable to anyone?

—Quite apart from anything else, the question is based on a completely false premise. There is no question about this particular investment being in the nature of a risk taking commercial venture operation. For Senator Baume to say that I have gone on record as saying that the purpose of this particular investment was to lease it out and receive a tax benefit from it is one of the more comprehensive whoppers even he has ever been guilty of in this place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume cannot find a single line that I have said anywhere which would remotely give rise to that interpretation. When I was asked across the chamber how this thing might be affordable in this kind of environment, given the order of magnitude of the investment involved, without even beginning to take into account considerations like the return on the property that Mr Keating already has and which he will, no doubt, sell as part of this particular transaction—without going into any of that, I said it should be taken into account that properties of this kind do have a very high rental value and, on any view, that would make a pretty significant dint into any particular interest commitment that anyone got into.

It was simply in order to make the point, which is supremely self-evident to anyone else in this country who has ever been involved in a house purchasing transaction or a succession of them over the course of their lives, that it is possible to upgrade one's family housing in this particular way as a result of the operation of market forces, without embarking on any other enterprise commitments at all. In those circumstances, Mr Keating is engaged in nothing more than all the rest of us have been engaged in throughout our adult lives when buying houses for our families and, as the occasion has arisen, upgrading that housing. Many of us, including me, were lucky enough to ride a housing price boom in this respect. I do not know whether Senator Baume was, and I am not in the slightest bit interested. Nor should anybody else be interested in the details of this, which simply do not bear upon Mr Keating's role in public life. It is once again a grubby, sleazy attempt by Senator Baume to get his head down in the muck barrel, again with his little legs waggling up in the air, his snout down in the slime trying to find something to throw. Why does he not get back to policy issues? Why does he not do something useful for a change? He is a waste of space at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think when the minister goes on in this manner he indulges in the politics of abuse. It was a very fair question, and the question was: to whom does Mr Keating declare his interests where there is a possible conflict of interest?
—Order! What is your point of order?
—My point of order is that you should have pulled him up and told him to stop speaking in that manner and answer the question.
—There is no point of order. Senator Evans, have you completed your answer?
—Yes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. All I am asking the minister is: will the Prime Minister reveal to the Australian people the same amount of detail about this commercial transaction—which he concedes is such; he said he wants to live in 2603 for a long time yet—that his ministers are required to reveal to him? Or is this Prime Minister not answerable to anyone? Is the minister aware that the reason this matter of principle is so important in Mr Keating's case is the genuine question of how a full-time politician could accumulate enough wealth to acquire a $2.2 million mansion for an investment when hundreds of thousands of Australians have lost their savings, their businesses and their homes because of Mr Keating's recession we had to have.

—Mr President, the politics of envy over there will not get Senator Baume or the Liberal Party or anyone he tries to con into supporting him any distance at all. The truth of the matter is perfectly straightforward, as I have described it. For Senator Baume to get up in this place and to put a question in the terms that he did, and I repeat, `that you'—myself, Evans—`have gone on record as saying that Mr Keating entered this transaction in order to lease out the premises in order to receive a tax benefit'; for him to attribute that to me as a purported quote, as a purported description of what I said—`in order to receive a tax benefit'—shows that Senator Baume is just a comprehensive, congenital, compulsive liar.
—Pull him up!
—Withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. It refers to the opening last week of the Brisbane Information Technology Centre funded under the federal government's skillshare program. What are the basic principles of information technology centres or ITECs as they are usually known? How many have been established? Has the ITEC concept, and the skillshare program in general, proved successful?

—I thank Senator Zakharov, who has had a long interest in training matters, for her question. There are 14 information technology centres, ITECs, across Australia which are run by community-based sponsor organisations. They are designed to enhance the practical experience that long-term unemployed and other disadvantaged job seekers have of information technology. Also, access to ITEC facilities is available to small businesses on a cost recovery basis.

PARA.TAB: The federal government provides up to 50 per cent of an ITEC's annual operating cost and the balance is met from industry, community contributions and income generated by the centre. In 1994 ITECs will receive $5 1/2 million under the skillshare program, one of the government's most successful labour market programs. Skillshare is delivered by community-based organisations and aimed at assisting long-term unemployed and other disadvantaged people to obtain jobs or to go on to further education training.

Skillshare has assisted more than 400,000 people nationally through vocationally oriented skills training and self-employment enterprise based activities. In 1994, 44 per cent of skillshare participants have been successful in achieving some form of employment, further education or training.

The Brisbane ITEC, which was officially opened last week, is sponsored by the Catholic Archdiocese of Brisbane. The centre will receive $176,000 in 1994 for the establishment of premises in the Brisbane central business district, the purchasing of equipment and the provision of training. During the remainder of this year it will provide structured skills training to 100 participants with a focus on areas such as PC maintenance, open learning and bookkeeping.

The ITEC concept is yet another initiative under this government that has proved to be very successful. In 1993 ITECs assisted nearly 5,000 participants nationally and they are well on the way to achieving the 1994 target of more than 5,000. During the first six months of this year 48 per cent of ITEC participants have been successful in obtaining unsubsidised employment on non-DEET funded education or training. This program, as part of the government's commitment in Working Nation to help the long-term unemployed, has been very successful. This, coupled with the excellent employment figures that came down last week of another 75,000 new jobs in Australia in September, shows that people have an opportunity to get jobs in the private sector market with, above all else, the government's well-targeted labour assistance programs such as ITECs and skillshare.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy or perhaps the Minister for Trade. I refer to the three primary industry victims of the GATT Uruguay Round—dairy, citrus and tobacco—which will have to undergo adjustments as a result of the GATT Uruguay Round schedules. In particular, I refer to the tobacco industry, which had its import tariff quota set at the high level of 11 million kilograms, which represents 70 per cent of consumption and which the manufactures industry and the government agree is too high, having been based on the very high 1986 levels. Now that the government has put in train reforms for the dairy and citrus industries, when is it going to announce its adjustment program for the cinderella of the victims, the Australian tobacco growing industry?

—I lost the raffle. Senator Collins and I have been in discussion with the tobacco industry about this matter. There have been more than just the GATT changes involved—and Senator Boswell is well aware of this. There have been three intersecting issues: the changes following the negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; the change in consumption patterns; and the Industry Commission report. These three events coincide to lead to a very tricky transitional situation for the industry.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission report was released on 1 September. We are assessing those proposals and we are consulting with the industry in the light of the report and our GATT and Uruguay Round commitments. Of course we know there is concern by growers and manufacturers. We have also had discussions with the Queensland state government, which has made some proposals about this. The replacement of non-tariff measures such as local content schemes with tariff quotas is an important part of the Uruguay Round agreement. Australia stands to gain considerable benefit from this—for example, through the opening up of the Japanese rice markets.

If we are to win in some places, we cannot avoid the consequences for ourselves. We have to look at how we accommodate them. The conversion of the local content scheme to tariff only protection had already been announced by the government in November 1988. The effect of the Uruguay Round outcome is to bring the action forward by some months, from September to an earlier date—either 1 January or 1 July next year. We will be continuing to consult with the industry about what should be done as a consequence. I accept that the industry has legitimate concerns. As I have said, they are not all caused by changes the government is making. They are significantly influenced by the very desirable—in my view—change in consumption patterns of their product. Nevertheless, some of the outcomes are caused by decisions implemented by the government to the benefit of Australia as a whole. In the light of that and the Industry Commission report, we will be continuing to consult with the industry. We will be looking at future tariff arrangements for tobacco which take into account our international obligations and those reasonable concerns of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his fulsome information but it was not exactly what I asked. The question I directed to him was fairly specific. He is bringing down a package today for the citrus industry that will reimburse it for the losses that are going to affect it through GATT. When is he going to bring down a similar package for the tobacco industry?

—I do not like to give specific dates when I cannot be absolutely certain, but my expectation is something like this—and of course there is negotiation, and sometimes in a negotiated process a bit of extra time is needed to get a matter resolved: broadly, the growers and the manufacturers are developing an industry response to the Industry Commission report, which we are expecting to get this month. I have not received it yet, but there is still quite some time to go. It will probably go first to my colleague Senator Collins. We will continue to talk with the industry and the affected states on the preferred position and options. There will be a submission brought to cabinet, once again probably initially by Senator Collins, for a government decision on the Industry Commission report. Our intention is to do that by the end of this year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the Port Hinchinbrook development in North Queensland, which has commenced. Is the minister aware of reports that the bund wall, which separates Stony Creek from the marina basin, is slumping and that material from the wall and surrounds represents a potential threat to the Hinchinbrook Channel? Is the minister confident that the wall will not collapse and that the appropriate officers of the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage have the expertise to make sound judgments on this matter? Will the minister assure the Senate that he will utilise the precautionary principle to protect the Hinchinbrook World Heritage area if the Queensland department is unable to do so? Is the Hinchinbrook Channel proclaimed under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act? If not, will the minister proclaim it now?

—I am aware of the media reports that the bund wall of the Oyster Point marina has collapsed. My department has advised me that, in fact, the wall has not collapsed although some soft material recently extruded from the bund wall into Stony Creek under the weight of heavy equipment. I am also advised that some of that material could be washed into suspension during heavy wet season rains. The site supervisor who has been appointed by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage is currently assessing the threat caused by this particular incident and obviously may recommend corrective measures as a result. I am not confident, and I cannot say in answer to Senator Woodley's question, that the wall will or will not collapse. But I have asked my department to undertake some further investigations into this matter and keep me advised.

PARA.TAB: In relation to Senator Woodley's question on the precautionary principle, he would be aware that the precautionary principle is a commitment by all governments under the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. The principle has been at play during this particular proposal. In fact, Senator Woodley might be aware of my advice to the Queensland minister, Ms Robson, that any progress in this matter should take place with extreme caution. That advice is in the public arena.

My department has assessed the information and advice that has been provided by Queensland authorities on the proposed program of environment protection measures in relation to this proposal. I wrote to the Queensland minister on 29 September this year advising her that, in my view, an extremely cautious approach should be applied to the project and, in particular, that there should be no dredging until and unless the results of proposed baseline studies are made available, appropriate standards are set and agreed to, and the monitoring programs are put in place to ensure the protection of World Heritage values in the Hinchinbrook Channel.

I sought agreement from the Queensland government that my portfolio would be involved in the development of the monitoring program and in the setting of environmental standards to be used for it to ensure that they are sufficiently stringent to protect those World Heritage values. As Senator Woodley would be aware, the Hinchinbrook Channel, up to the low watermark, is part of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area. I can say to Senator Woodley that the Hinchinbrook Channel has not been proclaimed under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to reported comments on page 1 of today's Financial Review detailing cabinet tensions over the government's deficit strategy, or, more properly, lack of strategy. I also refer to the Prime Minister's reported comments on 11 October in the Financial Review when he dismissed market pressure for action on the ever increasing deficit by saying overseas borrowings by Australian companies were agreements `between consenting adults, consenting borrowers and consenting lenders'. Where is the consent of the Australian people when the federal government's mismanagement of the economy is forcing our Australian companies to borrow offshore? Is Mr Keating's failure to address the burgeoning current account deficit a further indication of his complete disregard for battling businesses and families struggling with home loans? Finally, who will win the deficit strategy debate—Mr Keating or Mr Crean?

—This must be a weird day for the B-grade in the opposition—all of them have had a chance to ask an economic question. The latest participant in that is Senator Abetz. The trouble is that the question is a B-grade question as well. It would be very useful if we could ever get an A-grade question on the economy from the opposition. I am sure that Senator Evans and I will wait endlessly for such an event.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a series of newspaper headlines cobbled together to try to confect some sort of attack upon this government. I took down the words `the federal government's mismanagement of the economy' when Senator Abetz uttered them. Here we are, with an inflation rate of 1.4 per cent, looking at huge levels of job growth, with an economy growing at a level which is at the head of the OECD table—and having talked to a number of European finance ministers last week, I know they would like to have the figures that we have got—and Senator Abetz describes this as mismanagement!

There is a debate in the Australian community about the level of the deficit; that is true. But this government has a medium term deficit reduction program which will bring down the level of the deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996. That is a sound, forward looking program of deficit reduction strategy.Again, any other country in the OECD would dearly love to be in a position to have, and be able to deliver on, a program such as this. Australia stands tall among the rest of our peer group economies in being able to do so. And this is described by the opposition as mismanagement. What a laugh and what a joke!

The deficit reduction program being followed by the government is a responsible one. There is obviously a debate within the government as to whether we can speed it up. I think that is a good and healthy debate. It shows that the government is mindful of whether or not the micro settings of the economy can be judged and balanced a little better. But, as I said in answer to an earlier question, we make our figures on how the economy is progressing available towards the end of the year. When we do that, we will look again and that will enable us to make an informed judgment as we approach the next budget.

Meanwhile, all of those people looking forward to taking up new jobs in the economy, all of those employers whose profits in the most recent survey were at record levels for Australia, all of those people in industry who are enjoying the 53-year low in industrial disputation because we have developed a cooperative approach in the economy—none of those would agree with Senator Abetz that there is any mismanagement at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was not the Keating proclaimed and designed recession we had to have brought about in an effort to overcome our current account deficit? Is it not a fact that we still have the worst deficit of the OECD countries? Is it not a fact that the August current account deficit of $2.1 billion is a very sad reflection on this strategy? What is the government doing about this deficit that we have? How can government ministers sleep at night knowing that every single Australian owes the world $10,000?

—What we have here is a handful of Liberal Party slogans put together and pretending to be a question. There is no serious effort in this sort of weirdness that Senator Abetz has thrown up to pretend that there is a base in economic analysis. Senator Abetz knows and I know that we have been presiding over the restructuring of the Australian economy, and that we are in the process of making that transition from a closed, highly protective economy, bequeathed to Australia by Liberal and conservative governments, to an open and internationally competitive economy. During that period of transition the current account is bound to fluctuate in the way that it has. But if we look at the growth of exports out of this country, we see that the change is coming through and it is a change hailed far and wide by the community. As far as the rest of the question is concerned, it does not deserve an answer—and it will not get one.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The Canadian government recently announced a lifting of the 25 per cent out-of-quota tariff on certain cuts of beef imports. What does that announcement mean for our beef industry, and what has the government been doing to secure improved access for Australian beef exports to Canada?

—Many beef farmers, and those people in the Senate who seek to represent their interests, will greatly welcome this outcome, as I know Senator Denman and the Labor senators involved do. At a meeting I had this month in Jakarta with the Canadian trade minister, Mr McLaren, he informed me of the imminent announcement of the Canadian government decision to provide some improvement in access to the Canadian beef market for the remainder of this year. While that is welcome, it is clearly not sufficient as a solution to the problem which that government's current policies have created.

PARA.TAB: At that meeting, and at other discussions which I and other representatives of Australia—most notably the chairman of the AMLC, Mr Kerin—have had, I raised, as Mr Kerin and others have, Australia's continuing dissatisfaction with the unreasonable restrictions on access for Australian beef to the Canadian market in terms of arrangements for 1994 and Canada's failure to address our concerns with its proposals for a post-1994 Uruguay Round settlement on beef access.

For quite some time we have been trying to get a change both during the course of the negotiation of the GATT round and via Senator Cook and other trade ministers, and Senator Collins and his predecessors in primary industry. Even the Prime Minister has raised it with Prime Minister Chretien. In July I wrote a letter to Mr McLaren, and I discussed it with him in April. So we have been trying on and off for years. Mr McLaren told me that the Canadian government intended to lift the 25 per cent surtax for certain cuts of manufacturing beef for the remainder of the year.

The effect of the decision which was announced on 7 October will be to provide some relief to the Canadian processors who have insufficient domestic supplies of manufacturing beef to carry them to the end of this year. We welcome the Canadian initiative to allow more Australian beef to flow across its borders; it may not be Australian beef—it is up to us to win in the marketplace—but we are very confident it will be. This will provide added opportunity for Australian exporters. It is a very small step in the right direction, but it underscores the argument that we and the industry have repeatedly put to Canada, that global access to the Canadian market needs to be higher.

The announcement made on 7 October is the second time this year that Canada has had to modify its 1994 import regime to ensure that its processors have sufficient supplies. Ensuring that Australian beef exports secure better access to the Canadian market is a very high priority for the government, and we will continue to pursue it. It is very hard to understand why a government would have a policy that says its consumers cannot have good beef at low prices and its processors cannot be competitive because they cannot get access to the product, but this is the policy of the Canadian government, and we continue to make representations to seek to change it.

I do not want to underestimate the extent to which we appreciate the change that has been made. It will be better for the rest of this year for Australian beef exporters. It will open up a market, and I am very confident that we will win a fair share of it. But the bottom line is that the Canadian government must act to roll back its beef import restrictions against fair trading nations such as Australia. We are not asking the Canadians to give us a handout or to give us some special assistance or to do us a favour. All we are asking them to do is to recognise their own self-interest, the self-interest of their consumers and their processors, and to act accordingly. Australia will then take its chances on succeeding in the international marketplace in beef where I think we will win.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 13 October Senator Spindler questioned Telstra's shield of the crown immunity. I have further information to give to him as promised. Senator Spindler also asked about the legal advice given to the AFP on this immunity and the execution of search warrants, and the source of the AFP's legal advice and to what extent it influenced its investigations into Telstra. I think that is the broad ambit of the questions he asked last week. I gave some answers, but I can now add to those answers.

PARA.TAB: Concerning Telstra's shield of the crown, the AFP received written advice from the DPP in March 1994 that Telstra enjoyed this immunity and therefore the AFP could not execute search warrants under section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914. Nevertheless, the AFP investigation proceeded.

Following the submission of the AFP's brief of evidence to the DPP, the DPP indicated in September 1994 that there is now a contrary argument that a search warrant could be executed on Telstra. These conflicting views from the DPP were pursued with the Attorney-General's Department, which has indicated that, in its view, Telstra does not enjoy the shield of the crown immunity. The conflicting legal advice had little or no effect on the final outcome of the AFP investigations into alleged illegal telephone monitoring, I am informed, and also into the recording of customer services. A brief of evidence has been submitted to the DPP for adjudication, and I am therefore not in a position to comment on the nature of evidence collected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, you will remember that on 22 September 1994 you were asked a question in relation to reports that you had defended the use of Labor Party campaign funds to pay the private gambling debts of a Western Australian electoral candidate. In fact, you were reported in the press as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The party's image and reputation were at stake. I would have thought that a party's campaigning capacity would be affected adversely if a thing like that became public, and if it were regarded as necessary for the campaign I think it could be construed as being for a campaign purpose.
Mr President, in your answer to the question that was asked and in a statement that you read, you said:
I think there has been some terrible misreporting of these events.

Mr President, in order that fair play might be seen, and pursuant to your attack on either the professional competence or the integrity of the journalist concerned, will you obtain and table in the Senate a copy of the evidence that you gave in the trial of former Deputy Premier Parker? What you said may then be tested against what the journalist said so that everyone can see that justice is being done.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, I think in answer to a second question on that day, this has nothing whatever to do with the responsibilities that I hold as President of the Senate. As such, I had no intention of adding to the comment that I had already made. I do not see any reason to change that position.

—Mr President, you took the opportunity in answer to the question to attack the journalist concerned. You said that `there has been some terrible misreporting of these events'. Surely you would agree that, in those circumstances, and in the circumstances in which you, in effect, attacked either the competence or the integrity of the journalists concerned—not only the journalist Margot Lang, whose report I read a moment ago from the West Australian on 13 September, but also journalists Colleen Egan and Amanda Bower from the Australian and Duncan Graham from the Sydney Morning Herald, who all reported in similar terms on the same day—it would seem fair that your transcript be tabled in order that the reports of those journalists might be judged against your statement.

—by leave—As we said when this matter was first raised in this place, there are things that are within the proper role of the President of this place and there are matters that are entirely without it in which the President, for all practical purposes, is acting as a private citizen. If there is nothing in the conduct in question that bears upon the President's or, for that matter, in similar circumstances, a minister's capacity to do the job which he is responsible in this place for, there is no basis on which these matters can or should properly or sensibly be pursued.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter for your discretion, I would suggest, Mr President, as to how you want to respond to this invitation—as it might politely be described—to add something further to the record on this, but it is not something about which you have any obligation whatsoever to respond. It is a matter for your judgment, and your judgment alone. I would well understand, and I am sure all fair-minded people would well understand, your taking the view that if others want to pursue this matter they can do so in other forums and other places which do not waste the time of the Senate. The fact of the matter is that we are not dealing here with anything that bears upon your capacity to carry out this job or your responsibility to carry out this job.

If Senator Hill wants to create another opportunity for some paper to be tabled and some further debate to occur in this place, that is, I suppose, his political prerogative; but it should be seen for what it is—a naked exercise in political opportunism, together with a little bit of fishing to go with it, in the hope that if he fiddles and pokes around long enough something will turn up that might conceivably be halfway embarrassing to someone. It is not an assumption that any of us on this side of politics or the chamber would share.

I simply make the point, Mr President, that you are under no obligation to respond. It is entirely a matter for your own judgment as to how you do it, but should you choose to stick with the judgment that you have made—that there is no need for you to respond further because it does not bear upon your responsibilities in this place—you will have the support, I am sure, of all honourable senators in this place for taking that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, you are not under any legal obligation. But I would have thought that, holding a very high office in this parliament, you do have an obligation to those who would otherwise be perfectly entitled to complain about remarks made of them—that they had been guilty of incompetence in their professions. Journalists do not go around deliberating misreporting people; they normally do their best. If you were suggesting in those remarks that a whole series of journalists had got it fundamentally wrong, I would submit to you that you do have an obligation to set the record straight.

PARA.TAB: I will be very interested to hear you tell this chamber that when you gave evidence you did so in your capacity as a private citizen and you made it plain to the court that you were indeed not there as the President and did not even mention the fact. But, in any event, you cannot avoid being the President of the Senate, much in all as you might like to run away at times from that responsibility. You did choose to respond when these matters were raised some weeks ago. You did put a version on the public record, and if that version is challenged by others, you have an obligation to set the record straight.

It seems to me that journalists are entitled, like any other person in this place, to know the basis on which politicians make remarks. We often complain about coward's castle and how we have the right to defame or to criticise those who then do not have much recourse. If they really understand the system they might be able to come in here and have a statement tabled. But for professional politicians to embark on an exercise of denigrating those who write about them without providing any just cause, I should have thought, does your office and your reputation no good at all. And in those circumstances you owe it to us all, and particularly to those who are adversely affected by your comments to date, to table that transcript so that we can all make fair judgments about what really took place.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will make two brief comments. Senator Gareth Evans's remark that it is of no interest to this Senate whether the comments you, Mr President, made to the Senate were in fact accurate or not, is really a totally astonishing statement in my view. You made a very careful and considered statement to the Senate. Views have arisen that there is some question about some of these comments and it is important that this matter be cleared up.

PARA.TAB: The other point I would make is that I have tested in this chamber on a number of occasions how wide the responsibilities of ministers go and, of course, by implication how wide the responsibilities of a President go. You have always taken—I think wrongly, to be quite frank, but nonetheless it is the precedent you have set—a very expansive view of the range of issues on which a minister can comment in response to a question. Your particular responsibilities do go to the veracity of the statement which you laid before the chamber. In the interests of all parties involved, yourself and the journalists, it is better that this matter be cleared up and cleared up quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There is no complaint, as I understand it, from the journalists in this matter. If the journalists have complaints about what you or anybody else have said in this chamber there is a procedure that they can go through. If they want to do that, I have no doubt that you will have that matter referred to the Privileges Committee, a member of which sits next to me here. But, as I understand it, there is no complaint from any journalist at all about what you have said.

PARA.TAB: What has happened in this issue is that the opposition has said, `Do we know whether this statement you have made is true or not?' Then the opposition has presumed that, having raised that question, the whole matter becomes a matter for you to resolve. If opposition senators want to have a look at the transcript of the trial, it is open for them to go and do that and to come back and say, `Mr President, we have looked at the transcript of the trial and that is different from what you have said. What are you going to say about it?' It seems absolutely incredible for the opposition to come in here and raise an issue without any evidence at all and expect you to do all the work.

If the opposition, or any member of it, wants to see whether what you said was correct or not, that is an easy way for it to be done. But to get up and to simply raise the issue without any evidence at all that you have made a statement that is not accurate—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no evidence that the President has made an inaccurate statement. Until some evidence is given that what you have said is not true, then you ought to stick by what you have already said. If opposition senators want to go and do something about it, let them do it; but until that is done, you ought to stick by what you have already said. To do anything else would be an admission on your part that what you have said is not accurate. You ought to stay with what you have said.

—I stand by the statement I made that was referred to by Senator Hill. I stand by the decision I made after that not to make any further comment on the grounds that this does not bear on the responsibilities that I hold as President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day, relating to investments of the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought I asked a fairly simple sort of question that basically related to the fact that ministers of the Crown are obliged to reveal to their Prime Minister when they undertake any liabilities or acquire any assets. The cabinet rules state that they must reveal this in terms of the actual amounts of money involved. They cannot just say, `I bought a piggery' or `I intend to buy a piggery at some stage.' They have to actually reveal the details to the Prime Minister. I might say in passing that at no stage were such details ever revealed to Prime Minister Hawke when Treasurer Keating bought his piggery.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps that is an indication of why there is no feeling that Mr Keating need to report to anybody. He is accountable to nobody in the present matter. If it were one of his ministers who had acquired this $2.2 million investment property, then that minister would have been obliged to reveal to his Prime Minister the amount of exposure he had to risk—in other words, the volume of borrowings—so that the Prime Minister could be aware of any otherwise unknown potential for any conflict of interest. That is a simple principle, but whom does the Prime Minister report to when he is involved in the purchase of an investment property?

We heard the most incredible weasel words from Senator Gareth Evans today about whether or not this was an investment property. He very selectively quoted from two lines of his answer instead of quoting from the rest of it. Apparently he is at last getting a copy of the Hansard to see what he really said. I am so glad he is, because he will see what he said. I will help him; it is on page 1296. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the present environment, the Prime Minister will have no hesitation whatsoever in entering into a very long lease indeed in order to lease out that particular property and derive a sufficient income . . .

The interesting thing there is that I suppose we should take no notice of what Senator Evans volunteers in this place because it is not a matter of substance. He manages to recall lots of things, except important things, and he obviously failed to recall this little bit. It seems to me that here we have evidence from Senator Evans that `he imagines' that the Prime Minister had no hesitation whatsoever. One would presume he would not dare make such a response without prior consultation with the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: In any event, the Prime Minister's own evidence in the other place last week was that he had no intention of living in Woollahra for as long as possible and that his address, which he hoped to maintain, was 2603. By the way, I think he has got the postcode wrong, but that does not surprise me. The fact is that the Prime Minister himself has conceded that he will not be living in that Woollahra property. His principal place of residence, as he wishes, will be in Canberra at the Lodge, and he made a lot of fun, song and dance about it.

So the facts are simply these. Here is the Prime Minister going into a commercial venture where, according to Senator Evans, he will have no hesitation whatsoever in entering into a very long lease. He exposes himself to commercial risk. If it were one of his ministers, the minister would have to reveal that to the Prime Minister. Who does the Prime Minister reveal his exposure to? He reveals it to himself, and it is probably not a pretty sight!

The fact is that Prime Ministers do not enter into this kind of commercial venture for this very reason. The only people they can properly report to after they have been elected, because the people did not know they had this exposure beforehand, would be the Australian people who elected them. That is why Prime Ministers generally do not enter into this kind of venture. If they do, they must report it properly to the Australian people.

But this Prime Minister is accountable to nobody. He believes he can break conventions such as this. He believes he can enter new commercial risk taking operations without being accountable to anybody. The Australian people are entitled to know about this. If this Prime Minister determines to break this sort of tradition, he should properly expose all his risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary once again to deal with Senator Baume, who is incapable of dealing with the higher policy issues that are appropriate for discussion in this place and constantly seeks to slum around the low ground, finding barbs to fire which do not ever find their mark.

PARA.TAB: The particular point of view that is involved in this whole transaction and which, I think, most Australians would overwhelmingly share is that expressed in the editorial in the Australian of 12 October, where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The outrage from the Federal Opposition and sections of the media about the Prime Minister, Mr Keating's purchase of a $2.2 million residence is misplaced. Mr Keating has simply done what many people do or hope to do—traded upmarket in the interests of his family's comfort and economic security.

That is exactly what Mr Keating has done. When the opportunity arose to get, within a kilometre or so of the property that he already has in Sydney, a better property from the point of view of his family, a property that is better constructed and better laid out for his family as they get older—in particular, with a little flat out the back, which he is anticipating will be used by his son, who is not a kid any longer and is now approaching a reasonable age of maturity—the Prime Minister grabbed that opportunity with both hands, and it is entirely appropriate that he should do so.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to reveal all the circumstances of Mr Keating's financial arrangements as I know them. All I will say is that it is perfectly reasonable to anticipate this particular transaction being paid for with the sale of his existing Elizabeth Bay Road property, which is worth in the order of $1 1/2 million as a result of the upgrading that has been done on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not according to the experts.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Baume began his question today, premised as it was on this notion of commercial risk in a commercial investment, he purported to quote me as having gone on record as saying that Mr Keating was doing this in order to derive a tax advantage from it. PARA.TAB: So the only point in issue there is deriving a sufficient income from it in order to cover whatever interest payments might be due on whatever sum of money it might be necessary to borrow in order to cover the gap that arises between whatever he realises on the sale of the existing property. The answer that Senator Evans gave us was that he is not. Whereas Senator Evans would have to declare his borrowings, assets and so forth, Mr Keating does not.

Then the issue was raised as to whether this was a commercial transaction. Senator Evans fulminated long and loud in question time and, as usual, had an unpleasant whack at the questioner. But it seems to me that a fair reading of the answer that he gave—which he, himself, read into the record—is that this is a commercial transaction. Senator Evans said that when someone purchases a property which is designed to be leased out—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are not able to live in it, you have got to fund it somehow until you are ready to live in it.
—That is irrelevant. When someone buys a property which is then leased out, that is a commercial transaction.
—Wide of the mark.

—Senator Loosley shakes his head. Senator Loosley's experience in this area is not great and neither is his record. This is a commercial transaction and it raises the issue of taxation and negative gearing. Mr Keating has very large borrowings. He abolished negative gearing and then he brought it back.

PARA.TAB: I put it to Senator Evans that he gave a very poor response to the issues that Senator Baume raised. There is an issue of principle of disclosure of conflict of interest. If Senator Evans had come into this chamber and said, `We will follow the practices of this government'—I do not know whether this would have been satisfactory, but he could at least have said it—`as we tell Mr Keating of our transactions so, on the other hand, does Mr Keating inform his cabinet of his transactions,' that would have been an answer of sorts. While it might not have been a satisfactory answer, at least it would have been an answer of sorts. But Senator Evans could not say that. All he could say was, `We have complete confidence in Mr Keating.' As for the second aspect, namely, whether this is a commercial transaction, I put it to Senator Evans that his answer last Monday, 10 October, and reconfirmed by him today in this chamber confirms the point that clearly this is a commercial transaction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette this day, relating to the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: In noting the minister's comments regarding the international convention on climate change, we should recognise the emerging difference of opinion within the government regarding these sorts of international treaties. Last Thursday, I asked Senator Faulkner whether the government would delay its proposed signing of the international convention on desertification. Senator Faulkner dismissed my plea in that regard. He did so quite aggressively, saying that—

TALK.START.PARA: —But not Senator Evans.

—I will come to Senator Gareth Evans in a moment. Senator Faulkner said that he did not give a damn about the coalition's inquiry. In my question I had referred to the committee of inquiry the coalition had established into the government's proposal to sign this treaty, and to the overwhelming response we had received by way of submissions from very significant community groups, including the Australian Mining Industry Council, the National Farmers Federation, state farmer bodies, local government authorities and many individual farmers, pastoralists and other interested community representatives.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner said that he did not give a damn about any of that. He may not give a damn about those wide ranging and many submissions that were lodged with our Liberal and National parties committee of inquiry but, in contrast, foreign minister Evans, while confirming that the government would proceed to sign this convention over the past weekend, said that the government would consult widely before deciding whether to ratify it.

I make the point that that is a very significant change in the government's attitude to this matter. It is a major victory for the inquiry that was undertaken by the Liberal and National parties because, quite apart from the nature of the convention and the government's intention to sign it, the major issue that was raised with our committee in relation to this matter was the government's failure to consult sufficiently widely in the community before it made a decision to sign this convention and ratify it.

This lack of consultation was raised again and again in submissions to our inquiry. As I said, it is worth noting that Senator Evans has now said that, although the government has proceeded to sign the convention, before it proceeds to the next step—ratification—the government will consult widely. I notice that Senator Evans has included a bit of a fairy story in that statement because in his press release on Friday he said that this would be done consistent with the government's practice of widespread consultation. Of course it is nothing of the sort because the government does not consult on these issues.

As I have just said, one of the main complaints about the decision to sign the convention was the government's failure to consult sufficiently widely. Nevertheless, we have the recognition now with regard to ratification that the government intends to consult with relevant community groups, including industry and state governments. I welcome that and note that it is a direct result of the pressure that has been put on the government by this inquiry of the opposition parties. But mere consultation regarding the ratification of this convention is not enough because there are other issues of importance besides consultation. That consultation must bear fruit.

First, unless state governments, relevant industry groups and other community groups involved in the process of consultation that the minister has promised agree to ratification, the government most definitely should not proceed to ratify this convention. Secondly, the community and certainly we in the opposition will not be satisfied until the government goes one step further and unequivocally rules out the use of the external affairs power via this convention to interfere in the land management decisions of state and local governments.

We recall that earlier this year when the then minister for the environment, former Senator Richardson, was questioned about it, he refused to rule out that possibility. He refused to rule out the possibility that the federal government, when it proceeded to sign this international convention on desertification, would in the future use that power to take control of land management from the states.

The government must now make an unequivocal statement that it will rule out that abuse of the external affairs power. If the government ratifies this treaty community fears about the nature and intent of the government's signing of it will continue. They will subside only if the government unequivocally rules out the abuse of the external affairs power to override the states with regard to land management.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
