SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Abetz this day, relating to the current account deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the deficit that this economy labours under is a burning issue that needs to be dealt with. Clearly the August figures indicate that, rather than getting better, the situation is getting worse. In August we returned a figure of $2.1 billion—in other words, a $2,100 million deficit for the month of August.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that we have the worst deficit of all the OECD countries. Whilst Australia is suffering from this problem, we have government ministers fighting amongst themselves as to the appropriate strategy for dealing with this burning question. Whilst the Australian economy is sinking, we have the spectre of government ministers arguing about how to rearrange the deck chairs.

This problem needs a proper assessment and has to be dealt with. But this government does not have the will, the capacity or the foresight to deal with the problem after its last attempt. Let me simply remind the Senate what the last attempt was. The last attempt to rein in this burgeoning current account deficit was to initiate the recession we had to have, in the words of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. We had to have this recession to overcome our burgeoning current account deficit, our overseas debt.

We went through all the pain of that. We are now emerging from that recession and the simple question needs to be asked: has the current account deficit improved? The answer is no. Has our overseas debt improved? The answer is no. So we have gone through all of this pain for no benefit whatsoever. It is for that reason that the answer given by Senator Cook was so poor. What he told us was that the rate of unemployment is decreasing and economic activity is increasing. That is true, but from what benchmark? From the benchmark, from the low, that the Labor Party established as a result of its deliberate economic policy of creating this recession that we had to have. So its attempt to deal with the problem has been an absolutely dismal failure.

As a result, when people in this chamber ask questions about the government's deficit strategy—my colleague and friend Senator Gibson asked a question about it today; I asked a question about it today—we get pure invective from a minister who is unable to grasp the problem, deal with the problem or provide a solution to the problem. So what he does, as is so much the style of these Labor ministers, is to turn the attack on the questioner instead of dealing with the issues of the day.

The simple fact is that every man, woman and child at the moment is indebted overseas at the rate of $10,000. I cannot help noticing that there is a school class in the gallery at present. Each of those students will start his or her adult life with a $10,000 debt hanging over his or her head as a result of the incompetence of this Labor government in dealing with the economic problems that it created.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell them about the private sector debt and state government levels of debt. Fill out the story.

—I have been invited to fill out the story, and I will. The simple fact that we have an overseas debt by government and the private sector means that they have to borrow from overseas to be able to pursue their economic ends because of the mismanagement of this economy by the Labor government. If Senator Forshaw wants me to highlight it, I ask him to move for an extension of time for me so that I can speak for another 10 or 20 minutes on this issue. But I am sure he would be too gutless to do it because he would not want the government's pathetic record on this issue exposed even further.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that every man, woman and child in Australia is indebted overseas to the tune of $10,000. That is a disgraceful record, especially after Australia has been through such a terrible recession for no benefit whatsoever. Let me conclude my remarks by simply saying that if the people of Australia want the deficit to be dealt with they will need to elect a Downer-Costello government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Keating Government to match its politically inspired rhetoric in relation to the arts with concrete action that will enable the arts community to give full expression to its abundant creative skills and talents.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Alston, I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I will ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arts ought to be an occasion for celebration for all Australians. Indeed, cultural diversity offers us a great opportunity to ensure that we do not lapse into totalitarianism, that we do not become a country with only one view of the world, and that in many respects we are able to become a much more vigorous and outward-looking nation. Instead what we are finding is quite the opposite.

PARA.TAB: The government is hell-bent on intimidation of those it disagrees with, punishment of those that did not stand up and support it at the last election, and has a Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who is basically a cultural phoney. It is all very well to say that the Prime Minister is interested in the arts; I do not doubt that for a moment. The only trouble is they are not ours. His interests are Eurocentric. He is interested in European collectables and Mahler and other forms of European music. He is certainly not interested in Australia. We know from Mr Hawke what Mr Keating's true view of Australia is. Not only that; we know—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Well, I was there today when he did not deny it, and indeed everyone else found it to be profoundly accurate. Not only that, of course—
—What is wrong with Mahler?
—I am simply saying that he has no track—
—Australians play it pretty well.
—You see, even then the view of the world held by of those opposite is that if it is simply derivative, if it is a repetition of the great masters, they are not interested.
—Australians playing the best there is is worth hearing.
—Absolutely. But my point is that—
—He likes Sculthorpe as well.
—No. What he likes is European culture. He does not want to spend any longer than he needs to in this part of the world—
—We are going to ban Australian orchestras playing any European-based composer?
—Absolutely not; in fact quite the opposite.
—What about Bell Shakespeare?
—Are we going to ban Shakespeare now?

—Certainly not. What I am saying is that the Prime Minister is not interested in Australian culture at all. He spends as little time as possible here. His idea of a good time is trawling the antique shops of either Queen Street, Woollahra, or Paris, London or Rome whenever he can get out of this country. He has no connection with and no interest in Australian culture. He would not know one end of a football from the other, yet he pretends to barrack for Collingwood. He quite offensively talks about Hill's hoists as though this is one of the cardinal sins of Australian society.
—Have you heard of the Canterbury-Bankstown rugby league side?

—Canterbury-Bankstown; yes, I have actually. He would not know how to get there with a road map; we all know that. The fact is that he is not interested in Australian culture; he is interested in his own narrow view of the world.

PARA.TAB: He is interested in how much he can spend on clocks; how much he can get Warren Anderson to buy them from him for—perhaps at ten times the going rate. He is interested in how much he can spend on things that are utterly remote from the interests of ordinary Australians. I would have thought that Hill's hoists are something that most people find quite functional. People are quite proud to have them in the backyard. But the Prime Minister goes around bagging them. He thinks it is appalling that Australians should have to be stuck with a quarter-acre block. He thinks it is outrageous that the Cahill Expressway should interfere with his view from Kirribilli House. He is quite happy to go around offering $150 million to tear it down.

What are we going to see in the government's statement tomorrow? Presumably it will be something of that order spent over about four years—in other words, a pretty token gesture. If those opposite do not believe my view—

TALK.START.PARA: —You would spend more, would you?

—In due course Senator McMullan will find out. We normally have a look of complete disdain on the part of Senator McMullan. His usual tactic is to close his eyes, to roll his eyes, or he ignores one completely. Today he is in an absolute frenzy. There is a good reason why he should be in a frenzy: this is what his Prime Minister said on the eve of the last election:

SPEECH.PARA: We have had great support from the arts. They were all there again tonight. We ought to give them a bloody big kick along as well because they really have not had a kick along. They always say Labor is for the arts. Of course we are for the arts. But what have we done for them?

PARA.TAB: Firstly, what do the funding initiatives in Distinctly Australian and the Distinctly Australian budget package seek to do? They seek to encourage the production of the best that Australians are capable of producing and to fund the new, the risky, the cutting edge and the things that challenge the conventional wisdom. They do not always make people such as members of parliament comfortable. They get out there and do things that we might disapprove of. They say things that we do not agree with. They challenge the things we say.

But that is one of the great roles of arts in a democracy. That is why we have arms-length funding and why we have to accept that decisions are sometimes made which we do not agree with. This does happen; the Australia Council makes such decisions. Key things are issued in ways that maybe I would not do, but they are done by honest Australians doing their best for the arts as they see it, and I respect and endorse their decisions. They are at least as valid as mine or Senator Alston's.

Secondly, the funding initiatives allow maximum participation. One of the most unfair things that Senator Alston said in his criticism related to the question of the Sydney focus. One of the most significant changes that have taken place—not just since the election, because some were during the last term of the government; but, to generalise, let us talk about what has happened since that period—has been the enhanced access of Australians, wherever they live, to the best that Australian arts have to offer. This is done through the playing Australia, the performing arts touring program, the visions of Australia program, the visual arts touring, and there is more to come.

I cannot, of course, announce it today. If Senator Alston had wanted this debate tomorrow, we could have discussed the substance of it. But I can tell him that there is more to come: getting the best that there is out to where people are so that the taxpayers who fund it in Alice Springs, Mount Isa and Darwin, wherever they live, can see the best that Australia has to offer; and allowing the maximum opportunity for individuals to participate, irrespective of their wealth, in developing their talent as best they can through enhancing arts training.

Tomorrow we will announce something particular for Aboriginal and Islander arts training. I can say that because that builds on a commitment that I announced when I was arts minister, so it is not a `leak' of tomorrow's statement. The detail will be in that statement. The people who most need that assistance will be getting it, as was the case with the Australian Youth Orchestra when we set out to make sure that, wherever one lived or whatever one's income, one had an equal opportunity to participate if one had the talent.

The arts and culture is an industry that employs a lot of people. We aim to recognise it as an industry, to develop it as an industry and to develop its capacity to export. It is arguably one of our top 10 industries—one could get into a definitional debate and I am not interested in that today. However one defines it, it is a substantial industry, an industry that employs a lot of people, that generates a lot of wealth as well as providing a lot of pleasure, and it is developing an increasing capacity to export effectively.

We are providing more assistance as a result of previous budgets and the activities of Austrade to build on those exports. We will do more. The arts and culture industry has a tremendous capacity to project an image of Australia, first of all to ourselves, which in some ways is the most important, and also to the rest of the world. We will be doing more about that tomorrow also. If Senator Alston had wanted to debate the substance of that, he would have waited till tomorrow, until after the statement came down. We then could have talked about priorities and whether he liked the way we were doing it and whether we were putting enough money into it.

It is fascinating to watch honourable senators opposite—no wonder they like being in opposition; it gives them a certain comfort. On the one hand they can say, `Public spending should be less' but on the other hand they can then say, `Every area that I care about should have more spent on it.' Every shadow minister says that we do not spend enough, but the shadow finance minister says we spend too much. They cannot all be right. According to Senator Alston's matter of public importance—to which he did not actually refer in the sum total of his contribution—we have not substantially delivered the concrete action in support of the arts to match our rhetoric on the subject. But we have put the dollars there. Some people might say that we should put in more, but there is more than ever before. Funding was increased to $330 million in 1993-94, there was more again this time and there will be more again tomorrow.

So in two budgets and less than two years of government there has been a big increase in the budget and there will be a cultural policy statement tomorrow. The dollars are there, the commitments in principle are there and are available across the range to Australians wherever they live, whatever their income, to enable them to participate and to have access to the best that Australians have to offer. This is part of a systematic program that we have developed to enhance our cultural industries, to give national support to what is one of Australia's largest industries occupying a very significant place in the Australian economy.

As I said, we were supporting the arts in developing a comprehensive policy for the arts in Australia when it was not fashionable. I am delighted that we have made it a bit fashionable, and so other people are seeking to jump on the bandwagon. Welcome aboard! It is not that I am concerned that people want to jump on the bandwagon. I wish they had been on it earlier; they are very welcome. Unfortunately, the only seats left are at the back because the rest of us have been on the bandwagon for a very long time. We are seeking to continue the momentum and, to the extent to which opposition senators want to join in, argue about the priorities and seek to have more funding and more commitments, they will be very welcome on board.

But when we came down with Distinctly Australian and made the commitments in the last election about the importance of the arts to Australia, did those opposite recognise that and say, `Yes, we agree also'? No! They tried to attack the Prime Minister. Somehow, because he was increasing the profile of the arts, they attacked him for denigrating the coal industry. I never did quite understand that point. We think the inspirational capacity of the arts—

The Australian Democrats do not dispute the suggestion that the federal government's rhetoric in the arts has, for much of the last decade, not been matched by any real commitment to the Australian arts community. We need look no further than the Labor government's record in funding the arts since it took office in 1983 to realise that the arts community in Australia has not fared well in this country since the mid-1970s. It goes back, indeed, before Labor actually came into government.

It is on the funding criteria that the Labor government begins to look rather poor in this arts area. For instance, Australia's primary arts funding body, the Australia Council, has had to endure some very substantial funding cuts since the mid-1980s under the guise of the economic recession. This has meant that very little money has been available for new arts initiatives.

It is understandable that thousands of Australians who are involved in the arts begin to question this government's commitment to the arts when our premier arts organisation—the Australia Council—has been starved of funds. Its funding allocation has, in real terms, suffered a significant cut. Senator McMullan pointed out that there has been an upturn in the last year but, looked at in the totality of the time that Labor has been in government, the arts have not fared well.

The reality is that since Labor was elected in 1983, arts funding in real terms has been on the decline in this country. These funding cutbacks have significantly affected all sections of the arts community in Australia, including most obviously our performing and dramatic arts, as well as visual and music creators. At a time when it is widely acknowledged that the Australian arts industry is one of this country's biggest industries and a credible export earner, we should be encouraging and fostering our export industries and not starving them of funds.

The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics reports on the arts reveal, for instance, that the various Australian arts industries create in the order of $13 billion worth of goods and services, making them roughly the same size as the banking industry and twice the size of our sheep industry. Against this background, the Democrats have consistently maintained at budget time over the years that the government was making a huge mistake in seeking to reduce outlays by cutting funding to the arts.

It is true—and the Democrats will acknowledge this—that last year's federal budget represented a reverse of this trend as far as the Australia Council is concerned, but this increase has come after years of neglect. The government will need to continue to make real funding increases. I was pleased to hear Senator McMullan mention the intention to further increase funding in succeeding years. The government will need to continue these funding increases to agencies such as the Australia Council for many years to come if the damage over the last decade is to be repaired.

As a result, if the government wants to avoid the accusation that it has engaged in nothing more than politically inspired rhetoric in the arts, it will need to deliver a cultural statement tomorrow that includes substantial spending and policy initiatives for a multitude of arts activities. This must include considerable funding initiatives, especially towards agencies such as the Australia Council, the Australian Film Commission and Ausmusic, and in the specific area of Aboriginal and multicultural arts.

In tomorrow's arts and cultural statement, the Democrats will also expect government action in providing genuine incentives to encourage corporate support for the arts sector. Essentially, the Australian Democrats will want to see measures that will prove that the government is serious about fostering the commitment to the creative growth of Australian artists and to the economic development of our nation's culturally related industries.

In particular, this will require a sincere commitment by the government to the areas of arts infrastructure and creative development. In other words, if the government is to fulfil its promises to the arts community, there has to be the provision of specialist training facilities and opportunities for artists to develop their specialist skills. At the moment, these areas are seriously underprovided for, and their continued absence is severely limiting the potential of the arts community. The Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts is currently looking at education in the arts. Having looked at some of the submissions which have come in to that committee, I have found that there is a genuine and very consistent complaint about the matter of training in arts education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fine arts too.

—It is right across the board; not just in fine arts, but in the area of music, dance and visual arts. This will require action also in the important areas of strengthening Australian content guidelines. The Democrats have consistently advocated the need to increase Australian content in both broadcast and production levels. Australian content—particularly in television, whether free to air or emerging pay television—must be protected if we are to preserve and enhance our cultural heritage. Unless we can ensure an increased Australian emphasis in the areas of film, radio and television, Australia's very unique cultural identity will continue to be threatened.

PARA.TAB: We should, in this case, follow the lead of the French government and a number of other European countries which are correct to warn against and then oppose the dangers inherent in the most recent GATT agreement, which represents an ominous threat against each country's cultural and arts industries. I draw attention to both the government's and the opposition's support for GATT and praise the French—and honourable senators will not often hear me praise the French, but on this occasion I will certainly praise them—for their stand in protecting their cultural activities from being overrun by massive and cheap American exports. This most recently negotiated GATT agreement could see the end of a number of countries' arts and cultural industries which are reliant on government involvement to ensure that a nation's unique identity is fostered and portrayed in the arts.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Regulations and Ordinances Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, together with submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement on the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. On 25 August 1994 the Selection of Bills Committee referred the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for inquiry and report. This was the first time that a bill had been referred to the committee under the selection of bills procedures. The bill, which implements the government's response to the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council in its report on rule-making by Commonwealth agencies, makes important changes to the power of parliament to scrutinise delegated legislation and to access by the public to such legislation.

PARA.TAB: Delegated legislation, unlike primary legislation, is at present not always easily accessible to the public. The bill should substantially remedy this defect. It provides for an electronic register of all new and existing delegated legislation which the public will be able to scan to find legislation which may affect them. New delegated legislation will not be able to be enforced unless it is registered and existing legislation must be registered within a limited time frame.

The bill also provides for rule-makers to consult with affected parties when making delegated legislation which will affect business. This should ensure that any defects in the proposal are exposed and can be corrected before the instrument is made.

The bill also gives parliament a greater role in the scrutiny of delegated legislation. All legislative instruments subject to the bill will be disallowable, which is not the case at present. Delegated legislation must be tabled within six sitting days of registration instead of the present much longer 15 sitting days after making. A house will also be able to defer consideration of a motion of disallowance for up to six months.

For the above reasons the committee generally supports the bill, which should provide inexpensive and easy access by the public to delegated legislation with more effective control by parliament. The committee has, however, a number of concerns about specific provisions of the bill.

In particular, the committee has reservations about a power under which the Attorney-General may issue a conclusive and unreviewable certificate that an instrument is or is not a legislative instrument for the purposes of the bill. The committee recommends that these certificates be disallowable. Also, the bill provides for a power under which regulations may exclude rules of court from parliamentary scrutiny. The committee recommends that this power be deleted.

There are other less significant provisions of the bill which the committee suggests should be changed and the present report draws attention to these. None of the committee's recommendations, however, should adversely affect the operation of the bill, which is a major reform of the law affecting delegated legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson and Senator Panizza for expressing their concerns. Hopefully, I will cover their points in the explanation I will give. Both Senator Watson and Senator Panizza are concerned that the exemption is narrower under the new sales tax law than it was under the provisions which operated prior to 1 January 1993. Under the old sales tax law, exemption was available for transceivers which transmitted on RFDS frequencies even though use with the RFDS was only incidental.

PARA.TAB: Under the sales tax laws, exemption is available only for transceivers that are for use mainly—that is, more than 50 per cent—with a radio that is conducted by the RFDS. The RFDS provides an emergency service, including regularly scheduled services, and a public correspondence service. Both these uses and use of any other service conducted by the RFDS can be counted for the purposes of determining whether a transceiver is eligible for exemption.

When the new sales tax laws were introduced, it was decided to narrow the scope of the exemption for the following reasons. Firstly, there was evidence that the receivers were being used by transport operators, miners, et cetera in ways which had virtually no connection with the RFDS and that the exemption was therefore not serving its original purpose. Communications equipment is not generally sales tax exempt. The broad exemption under the old law resulted in anomalies in the sales tax treatment of various types of communications equipment. It would be very difficult to draft an amendment which would not be abused. The changes were noted but they were not emphasised in the explanatory memorandum for the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1992.

Senator Panizza has raised a further issue. He is concerned that the amendment will have the effect of excluding base stations from the exemption. Persons who wish to use any service provided by the RFDS must have an appropriate licence issued under the Radiocommunications Act. The exemption is available only to persons who hold these licences.

The explanatory memorandum states that the relevant licence is `an outpost station' licence, which is a licence usually issued in respect of mobile transceivers for use in the field. However, the exemption is not limited to any particular category of licence and could apply equally to a base station licence, which covers fixed equipment located in homesteads or other permanent locations. Transceiver bases can therefore qualify for exemption under the amended law.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I think this is an appalling situation given the importance of the use of radio transceivers, particularly in an emergency. It has always been the case that people have used transceivers for other purposes than real emergencies. As I said previously, it will thwart the purpose and the use of transceivers, which are absolutely invaluable in the event of such emergencies. Given the remoteness of areas and the need for speed, this legislation is a most retrograde step in terms of the services and recognition of the problems faced by people in the outback.

PARA.TAB: It is certainly not a good day for the outback or for the government so far as the outback is concerned because speedy response in emergencies is absolutely vital. It is an essential service in the outback of Australia. Not only can tragic accidents be avoided but the victims of those accidents can receive much more speedy treatment if these sorts of transceivers and this sort of equipment are more freely available. It has always been the case for most people using these transceivers that the `mainly for use' test—the more than 50 per cent test—could never be satisfied.

This is a safety issue. There should be a recognition of the special place that Australians in the bush have. In view of the wonderful response that Australians made to the appeal for funds for the Royal Flying Doctor Service the other day, with the cooperation of the ABC, I suggest that had Australians known about this legislation at that time, it would have been a very bleak day for the government, which is adopting a mean approach to what has become a traditional and very important Australian mechanism of communication.
