DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, once again the Senate gets the opportunity to address another very important and historic piece of legislation. On this occasion it is the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. This piece of legislation flows through in a continuum of legislation that has been brought about by the development of various aspirations for Aboriginal people throughout Australia, and in many ways brings together a number of the commitments and special obligations that were created and imposed by this Labor government following the enactment last year of the native title legislation that flowed through and followed from the historic Mabo decision.

PARA.TAB: It is incumbent on this parliament to look very carefully at all legislation of this nature. We have gone through a tremendous investment of time, a tremendous investment of issues, and a great deal of consultation with Aboriginal people throughout Australia and with many other interested groups who are affected by the import and changes that legislation can bring. It is also a very serious indictment that the government has to deal through legislation with so much of the correction of problems for Aboriginal people. I say that very sincerely. Since the referendum of 1967 governments have had before them an obligation to Aboriginal people throughout Australia that has not been properly addressed.

When we go to the issues that are fundamental in addressing what are often broadly described as problems for Aboriginal people, we must deal with and cope first with the very core emotions of why Aboriginal people themselves see `problems'. I would identify three important areas of core emotion that are generally defined by Aboriginal people.

The first is dignity: so many Aboriginal people throughout this nation, despite all the intent and changes of the last 20 or so years, are still paralysed by despair. The second emotion that Aboriginal people have to deal with is marginalisation: the feeling of powerlessness, of lack of participation, of lack of involvement in the wider community and what is so importantly caught up with it. The third core emotion that has to be dealt with is that of bitterness by Aboriginal people with regard to the issues that they must address, and this entire area that I would define as a feeling of alienation within the community.

When we track through those core emotions we have to go to the causes. What are the causes of them that still express themselves? Probably the most important one that I would identify is poverty; the second is that of identity. If I can talk for a moment about poverty: this expresses itself through the areas of minimal education, poor housing, homelessness and lack of accommodation, disease, ill health, alcohol and substance abuse, and, more recently, problems resulting in the health area of HIV and STD risks.

In the area of identity, it is often the wider community's problem because it has failed to address the ethical foundations of Aboriginal society. The community has not formed a proper and decent appreciation of traditional Aboriginal culture and, more recently in our society, contemporary Aboriginal culture, which must also be properly recognised.

How do these emotions and these causes manifest themselves? They have many effects and expressions in our community. Generally the ones that come before us, because they are so visual, are unfortunately the areas that are highlighted again and again by negative media. They are the areas of violence, discrimination, inappropriate administration and, very recently because of the things that have happened through ATSIC and other areas, leadership tensions in the community.

We must come back always to questioning the motivation of politicians, the motivation of bureaucrats and the motivation of Aboriginal people as they start to emerge through the broad community. Today, if anyone wanted to put together a library of events or academe or of good study of these issues in Australia, I am sure that we could almost call for a special library of Aboriginal interests in Australia. There have been volumes of words said and, unfortunately, it comes to this point of tension that we must always look at.

I was attracted to some papers that were produced recently by a group of Christian leaders who were attempting to address this issue. They sought to explore a range of issues and tried to involve so many of these areas that I have identified as core emotions or causes or effects. There were many prominent academics participating in that particular conference. There were a number of anthropologists, including Dr Stephen Davis and Dr Ron Brunton. There were a number of politicians including the Labor Party's Mr Graeme Campbell, the member for Kalgoorlie. Very interesting papers were presented by theologians across a wide scope of Australians. A very interesting paper was given by Sir Harry Gibbs, formerly of the High Court. I was attracted to many of the issues that were highlighted right through all of those areas.

One of the points made by Sir Harry Gibbs was that, according to the results of the last census, the indigenous peoples comprise 238,590 persons regarded as Aborigines and 26,902 regarded as Torres Strait Islanders; in all, just over 1.5 per cent of the total population. Sir Harry Gibbs broke that up by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Of the total number of Aboriginal people, 33 per cent live in rural areas, 24 per cent in major urban areas and 42 per cent in other urban areas.

Again, if we track back through all of those particular issues, we come up with these particular areas that need to be highlighted. Let me quote some of the other speakers at that conference. Dr Steven Davis, on culture, said:

Many anthropologists have for so long viewed Aboriginal cultural as being static. Of recent times with the many land claims and now native title claims it is becoming obvious that there is a significant fluidity in Aboriginal culture. It is clear that Aboriginal culture is not static but rather it is fluid, vibrant and dynamic.
Further, on bureaucracy, Dr Davis said:

In its knowing and presumptuous way the government has set up structure after structure to `cure the Aboriginal problem'. In fact, what has largely been achieved is the replacement of a bureaucracy dominated by whites, with a bureaucracy dominated by Aborigines with little if any traditional background. This new bureaucracy, Aboriginal in name only, does not reflect the traditional structure of Aboriginal authority. Thus the new quasi-Aboriginal bureaucracy has continued the work of much of the European bureaucracy in undermining traditional Aboriginal structure and destroying the social fabric of traditional Aboriginal life.
It was Mr Graeme Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who said:

The Aboriginal industry is a cancer which thrives on a guilt-induced diet of $2 billion a year and consumes the responsibility, independence and ultimately the dignity of the very people it purports to serve.

They are damning statements to a conference that set out to address this particular issue. They go a long way towards explaining why, in the challenge of the next 20 years, we cannot and must not repeat all of the mistakes and go over all of the problems and the financial wastage that have hurt so many Aboriginal people for so long.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the legislation before us today comes about after a decade of failure by a Labor government. That is a very severe and damning indictment. Looking back over that decade, let us address for a few moments issues such as the relationships in Aboriginal affairs between the states and the territories. What have they been? How have they manifested themselves? Basically, the situation has been of frustration and counterproductive effort. If we look at the initiatives that were highlighted in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and all of the programs flowed from it, basically we see that that was a camouflage. The results that have flowed through have been a camouflage by putting tags on government expenditure items.

There was the ATSIC dream. In 1989 in this parliament we set up a new bureaucracy which, as Dr Davis said, replaced a white bureaucracy with a black bureaucracy. Aboriginal people are now questioning the values of that ATSIC dream. The CDEP program is trying to introduce the work ethic. There are some very good examples of this throughout Australia but there are also a lot of failures. In the whole area of initiatives in the Department of Employment, Education and Training, training and education ought to be the outcome but, unfortunately, so many of those programs are doing nothing but creating false expectations.

In the area of land rights, which we addressed last year in the native title legislation, we can look through Labor's gospel and see that it does not produce results. Mabo, native title, and now this legislation do not guarantee what Aboriginal people are looking for. I know from my own electorate's point of view that if we look at the focus of the Northern Territory's land rights act and other legislation over a period we see that what has really emerged is a land council monopoly which for too long has been run by the Australian Labor Party's left-wing agenda. It has only been in the last year or so that we have started to see that issue being addressed fundamentally and the land councils moving away—and they have moved away—from this dominance of control that has created so many of these problems.

If we look very carefully at this legislation we see that it sets out to provide for the acquisition of land for Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders who are unable to benefit from native title. The bill also establishes the Indigenous Land Corporation to manage the acquisition of land and to provide for the management of land held by indigenous people. These are important aspirations and there are going to be very big tests.

Let me remind the Senate that we can certainly demonstrate from the Northern Territory's point of view that land of itself does not cure the issues of health. Aboriginal health is still appalling. Graphs that I have seen very recently prove very dramatically that when we relate mortality from all causes—respiratory diseases, infectious diseases, or diseases of the circulatory system—to areas where Aborigines have lived for ever, such as Arnhem Land or in the central parts of Central Australia, and where they have basically held land continuously, we find that the worst affected areas for mortality and disease are in those very areas.

In the Northern Territory, we have had the experience of the land rights act since 1976. There has been an important exchange of correspondence between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Perron, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) over this legislation that we are addressing today. Mr Perron has set out that there are major points that need to be made with regard to those areas. I was pleased to see that the Northern Territory Minister for Aboriginal Development, Mr Steve Hatton, appeared before the Senate committee that looked at this legislation. I note that my colleagues Senator Ellison, Senator Campbell and Senator Troeth, in their minority report to that Senate inquiry, highlighted many of those very issues that Mr Hatton and the Northern Territory government have been raising continually. In that regard, I seek leave to table an exchange of five letters between the Northern Territory Chief Minister and the Prime Minister on this matter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are so many issues that time does not allow us to address. I was pleased to note a paper that was delivered to my office in parliament house last week. It was distributed by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and by ATSIC. It was over the signature of Patrick Dodson, as chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and Charles Perkins, the deputy chairperson of ATSIC. It brought together a summary of reports of consultations right around Aboriginal communities. It is a very important document.

PARA.TAB: It refers to many of the issues with which we have had to deal here in this parliament—issues which, from a white man's perspective, we have been harping on far too often. It has often been felt that the criticisms were being imposed by the opposition, or by parliament, or by white fellas. But this is a document that brings together a whole series of consultations throughout the Aboriginal community. It highlights and brings home many of those same priorities—accountability, employment, housing—that are all so fundamentally related to providing benefits for those Aborigines who do not have land rights bestowed on them by the Northern Territory land rights act or by the native title legislation. Many of the issues are in the sections under access and equity, and equity and accountability, where Aboriginal people suggest options and float many ideas which I think are deserving of a lot of commendation and a lot of addressing. It will be incumbent on ATSIC, as the principal bureaucracy in this area, to pick up many of those issues and properly address them.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that last year I called for a special audit by the Australian National Audit Office into the land councils. That report was very important because it brought down some 53 recommendations for very significant change. Let me prophesy, let me point the bone, let me say that we must watch and be careful that any of the mechanisms we now create under this legislation to set up very special investment boards, handling sums of money which will accumulate to $1.5 billion, do not repeat those very problems into which the land councils got themselves.

The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) basically delegated his authority away from his essential primary responsibility in the history of the last five or 10 years, and millions of dollars, properly the property of Aboriginal people, were totally dissipated and wasted. The precedent of that report into the Northern Land Council is one that must, at all times, be read alongside this legislation and what we are now seeking to achieve.

This last weekend whilst I was in Canberra, I had the opportunity to look at the excellent art exhibition at the National Gallery. It is an excellent exhibition from the point of view of traditional Aboriginal art and also of modern urban art. Whilst much of that art in the modern urban section is very angry and very bitter, it is a very important statement by these Aboriginal artists and how—quoting from the catalogue—two artists in particular, Gordon Bennett and Richard Bell, `explore the development of negative stereotypes of Aboriginal people which have been created since the coming of Europeans and which led to popular misconceptions and downright lies concerning indigenous people'. That is a very fundamental expression in a visual form. In this legislation we are again trying to come to grips with it.

I turn to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which was tabled last week. The government acceded to a very cursory glance at this legislation and walked away from the fundamental responsibilities that the parliament needed to address. It was again left to my colleagues in the minority report to put down some 40 pages of recommendations which we will be bringing here by way of amendments. I note that the Australian Democrats and the Greens (WA) have been attracted to many of those fundamental issues but not the Australian Labor Party. It still wants to be run by a left wing, patronising agenda of telling Aboriginal people where and how they should be going. That is not the way this legislation should be progressed, nor is it in the best interests of listening to the voice of Aboriginal people.

Much is to be gained for this legislation in the whole spirit of reconciliation. Much is to be gained for Aboriginal people. There are many challenges in this legislation for all of us who have an important responsibility in progressing the Aboriginal people in Australia.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 is very important indeed. In fact, in December last year when this Senate engaged in what I believe is the longest debate in its history, on the Native Title Act, many people thought that that was one of the most important pieces of legislation which the Senate had ever dealt with. But not many people realise that the origins of this legislation are found in that part of the preamble to the Native Title Act which states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

So, at the start, we see in that legislation that the government acknowledged that there were two groups of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In fact, I recall the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) stating that five per cent or thereabouts of Aboriginal people would be able to claim native title.

PARA.TAB: This legislation really has much more to do with catering for the land needs of the Aboriginal population of this country. It is of wider application. I would suggest that the government has failed to recognise this in its legislation, because the spectrum of people this legislation should be looking after runs from an Aboriginal person in Redfern to a fringe dweller in Kalgoorlie in Western Australia. In fact, it was a matter raised in the recent report by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration—a report that I was thankful to be involved in and for which I had the privilege of taking evidence. Mr Aden Ridgeway, the executive officer of the New South Wales Land Council, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The principle consequence of moving the scheme from the Native Title Act to the ATSIC Act is that the preamble to the Native Title Act will no longer provide any assistance in interpreting the powers of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

That point was driving at the fact that the preamble to the Native Title Act, which I have just recited, is not to be found in this bill. I would have thought that the starting point would have been that part of the preamble of the Native Title Act to give this bill its proper direction; but, unfortunately, it is not and I believe that it should be incorporated in this legislation so that it remains a statement for generations to come as to what precisely this land fund is about. I questioned Senator Gareth Evans on this point during the course of the committee hearing that I mentioned. I said:
I understand that the purpose of this legislation is to cater for those Aboriginal groups which might not be catered for by the Native Title Act. Is that the case?
And he replied:
Yes, essentially. It also caters for those who are not able to take advantage of the provisions of the Northern Territory Land Rights Act, which will continue to have applicability until 1997.
So we need to be very clear at the outset about what this bill is intended to do.

PARA.TAB: The other aspect which needs attention in this bill is the criteria for granting land or for making grants in relation to the management of land. At the moment the bill provides that the purpose of such grants is to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I would have no quarrel with that. But there are wider aspects to be looked at in the granting of land and assistance for the management of land. I believe that the coalition's proposition for health, housing, educational needs, or economic viability just make commonsense in relation to how this land fund is administered. During the hearing I put to Senator Gareth Evans that the question of water and its availability might be a key issue in the granting of land to, say, fringe dwellers in an area where they have no native title but where they perhaps chose to live on the outskirts of a town because they have lived there for some time. I have no problem with that but one does have to look at the provision of water, sanitation and the basic conditions that any human being should enjoy. That is essential also in providing funds for land management because it establishes some priority.

We have already seen that the government coffers are limited. If there has to be a choice between two Aboriginal groups and one is in desperate need of funding for the management of its land which would incorporate dams and windmills, that needs to be included in this criteria for grants because another group that might need money for the construction of a shed or the clearing of property to improve it might not be in as much need as the former group. But the present criteria will not help in the determination of how to grant those funds. If this is to be incorporated in any sort of reconciliation process, it cannot be denied that matters such as health or economic viability are essential in the administration of this fund.

The other aspect is the preparation of national and regional land strategies. For my part, I would prefer to see regional strategies prepared before national strategies. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in a given region are much more equipped to provide input for their particular area than are bureaucrats in Canberra, but as this bill is structured, we have the national strategy and the regional strategies.

One of the problems I found during this hearing in relation to the bill was the lack of consultation by the government in assessing what exactly Aboriginal people wanted. I cannot speak on behalf of Aboriginal people, but I can certainly relate to the Senate what I heard in that hearing. I can tell honourable senators that Dickey Cox from the Kimberley Aboriginal Association and Robert Bropho from Swan Valley certainly had not been consulted sufficiently in relation to what they thought should go into this bill. I am not saying that those who came along and said that they had been consulted sufficiently had any case to answer in this matter. They certainly did not. The body that has the case to answer in this matter is the government. It is the government which had the carriage of this matter and the carriage of wide consultation.

Aden Ridgeway acknowledged that in the Aboriginal community we would find diverse opinion and differing views. There is nothing wrong with that. We would find that in the wider community of Australia. When dealing with human beings, if there are two in one room, people could bet their bottom dollar that there would be some sort of difference between those two people. There is absolutely nothing wrong with that but, having acknowledged that, does the government go further? Does the government go and consult with individual groups or does it just consult with the land councils concerned?

This is no criticism of the land councils; it is a criticism of the government for not seeing that there is more to the Aboriginal community and Torres Strait Islander people than just land councils. There are small groups, families and Aboriginal trusts all over this country that need to be consulted. That just was not done, and we can see that in the drafting of this bill because one of the fundamental flaws of this bill is that grants are available only to corporations.
In the Australian on 26 August this year, Noel Pearson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Meanwhile, strategies for self determination and self management—involving Aborigines managing structures imposed by non-Aborigines—was often mistakenly installed in its place.

He was saying that we used the structures of white men in order to govern the affairs of the Aboriginal people. If a corporation is not an Anglo-Saxon structure, then I am afraid I am absolutely mystified as to what it is. I believe the fundamental flaw in the Native Title Act was that we had this problem of title not being granted to individuals, and there was a good deal of controversy in relation to that.

PARA.TAB: I took part in the hearings in relation to the legal and constitutional committee in relation to that bill and there were a substantial number of witnesses who said that native title is a matter which should be enjoyed in an individual sense. I have had experience in Western Australia of communities which are not incorporated. I have had experience with families who exist and live in an area and are not incorporated. In fact, in some areas the number of indigenous people can be few and the setting up of a corporation may not be in their interests. This bill entirely overlooks that. Aboriginal groups have to be a corporation in order to fit in with this bill. It is the all-encompassing, centralist approach that this government loves to indulge in. That is where I say that this bill is fundamentally flawed.

Another aspect is that this bill allows for the granting of land which is separate to native title land. I put it this way: if the small percentage that the minister mentioned can claim a piece of land, then that piece of land should not be available for a land fund grant. The land fund is about giving land to those Aboriginal people who cannot maintain a native title claim. If we mix in the two, I tell the Senate now solemnly, we will rue the day because we will be encouraging division between Aboriginal people.

The situation could arise that we grant to one group, a dispossessed group which cannot maintain native title, a piece of land. We then have another group which can then maintain a native title claim over that piece of land and we then have a conflict of interests—a classic conflict of interests. We should insert provisions in this bill which ensure that as much as possible the Indigenous Land Corporation ensures that the land which is about to be granted or which it will acquire to pass on to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander groups is not the subject of a native title claim. That is another fundamental flaw.

There are other aspects, too, which concern me in relation to this bill and these were all raised in the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Briefly, the aspects of accountability in relation to the Indigenous Land Corporation, I believe, do not go far enough. I believe there is insufficient accountability, not only for the recipients of the land but also for the Indigenous Land Corporation itself. If we do not provide clear guidelines and rules of accountability, we leave a body such as the Indigenous Land Corporation open to attack.

We also do not provide that assurance to the recipients. For instance, there should be a time limit that if the Indigenous Land Corporation says it will grant land or do something it will do it within a certain amount of time so that the recipients know that they will get that within so many months, that such and such will be done in relation to the management of the land within a certain time.

I also stress that in relation to the running of the land in question the board should possess, among other attributes which are covered in the legislation as to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background, the attributes of some skill in the management of land. I am not saying that perhaps the whole board needs to have qualifications in relation to land management or land development, but there needs to be expertise on that board in relation to land management. After all, we have millions of dollars of taxpayers' money being used in the position of trust for recipients who really are placing their trust in the proper exercise of duty and management of this Indigenous Land Corporation. So the corporation owes two duties of care: one to the Aboriginal people it is supposed to be serving and the other to the taxpayer at large who is funding it. The government of the day needs to wake up to this and ensure that there is expertise there.

Another aspect which appeals to me is that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander members of that board should be as diverse as possible. I mentioned the differing views we had in the Aboriginal community and in relation to the hearing when we looked into this bill. I see nothing in this bill which states that the government should address that aspect; that is, to make a conscious effort to accommodate the wide group that we have in the Aboriginal community, not only land councils but also individual communities, fringe dwellers and urban dwellers so that the people from Redfern to the people living on the fringes of Kalgoorlie have some sort of representation on the board.

There are other aspects, which I will not go into detail about. Suffice it to say that when we are dealing with land tenure we have to provide protection to the land holder and also to third parties who come along and deal with the land. I believe the coalition has some commendable amendments in relation to third interests. This point was actually made in evidence by Aden Ridgeway. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any land or interest in land which is acquired by a body corporate with the assistance of the ILC other than by way of guaranteeing a loan cannot be sold, mortgaged or otherwise disposed of without the consent of the ILC. Any such disposal without that consent is deemed to be of no effect or null and void.

The Bill does not provide any mechanism by which the ILC is obliged to lodge any caveat giving notice of its interest. There is a very real likelihood that any third parties that may be involved in any land transactions or deals would be unaware of the ILC's interests, and those parties may be prejudiced by unauthorised dealings.

If this bill is not drafted correctly, if the government does not get it right in the first instance, it will only create division. If there are third parties who are the victims of, say, an unauthorised dealing in the land, I would put it to the Senate that the blame should rest largely at the door of the government for not ensuring that there were sufficient safeguards in this bill.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day, what we are about in this Senate is ensuring that the legislation we pass is proper, effective and achieves what it sets out to do. I do not believe this land fund does that. There are many flaws with it. I believe no-one could argue with the preamble that I cited at the outset, and it has much merit. But are we putting that preamble into effect with this intended legislation? That is the question. I would say to the Senate that indeed we are not.

We have a duty to ensure that every dollar is accounted for; that it is spent efficiently; that it benefits the recipients we intend to benefit; that it affords to the taxpayers security so that they know that their dollar is being spent properly; and that the people whom we set out to help know that they are getting the best help possible and that, along the way, it is not being wasted or it is not being lost in some giant bureaucratic machine.

The coalition has some worthwhile amendments, and I have also seen some other amendments, from other sectors not aligned to my party, that I think have some merit. The government's intransigence in this matter is

SPEECH.PARA: deplorable in the way that it just thumbs its nose at worthwhile amendments. Whilst it does that, no-one can take the government's motivation seriously or its intention to put into effect that preamble in the Native Title Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main reason why I want to speak in this debate is to answer a couple of the points made by Senator Ellison and his colleagues from the opposition who were members of the former Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration inquiry into the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. I first emphasise that this proposal for a land fund is not a new proposal. It is provided for in the Native Title Act. All that this bill does is transfer the administrative arrangements for that land fund.

PARA.TAB: The whole concept of it was part of the consultations and the debate leading up to the enactment of the Native Title Act. Despite the assertions about the lack of consultation by the opposition and by some witnesses before the finance and public administration committee, there was in fact a high level of consultation; and it is difficult to see how much wider the consultation could have been on this matter.

The other thing to emphasise that is mentioned in the majority report of the committee on this bill is that the issue of health and education, which the opposition has wanted to drag into this matter, is indeed a matter for the social justice package, which also is a relevant part of the whole dealing with this Aboriginal affairs matter, which was again part of the negotiations leading up to the drafting of the Native Title Bill and which is part of the overall process of the government in dealing with this matter. The land fund is dealing with the issue of land for those who do not have access under the Native Title Act. The social justice package is designed to deal with those other issues of education, health and so on. I am looking forward to that as the next step in this overall process.

The particular matter I want to draw attention to is one part of the opposition committee members' minority report. I would be particularly interested in Senator Ellison's response to this because I do not believe that he, Senator Campbell or Senator Troeth read the draft of this minority report before they signed it. I do not believe they could have. Obviously someone other than Senator Campbell, Senator Troeth and Senator Ellison wrote this minority report, but they have signed it and ought to take responsibility for it.

I could not work out whether to be angry, annoyed or just puzzled by the comments of Senator Ellison, Senator Campbell and Senator Troeth on this matter. Maybe they can explain to me at some time the basis of these comments. I will quote the last part of their minority report, under the heading `Witnesses Biased'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is one of the saddest indictments of a Senate Committee for the majority Government members to state at the outset of a report that it mostly invited witnesses that had some objection to the Bill. The ALP Senators then go on to reject all the evidence of the witnesses except that of the Minister, ATSIC and the Central Land Council.
It is a disgraceful and judgemental conclusion for the Committee to report they had called witnesses on the basis of their views.
The Chairman of the Committee should make an explanation to the Senate as to why he decided to invite a biased group to give evidence.

I guess I will be satisfied with just being puzzled about it rather than angry. But the point is that, in the discussions between me and Senator Campbell over who should be invited to give evidence to the committee, it was acknowledged, as it is naturally acknowledged by all committees when they are preparing a list of witnesses, that there should be an attempt to ensure that people who have particular suggestions to make about how the bill should be different are given some additional ability to give evidence.

PARA.TAB: The whole point of the comment in the report that most of the witnesses called were those who had some objection to the bill, I would have thought, was that it was just an obvious way of dealing with the bill. Senator Campbell knew that that was how we were approaching the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was making a judgment before they gave evidence.
—No, they were invited, as Senator Campbell knows, because they had some problems with the bill.
—There was no knowledge they had any objections.

—Yes, there was. That was why Senator Campbell suggested they be asked—because they had problems with the bill and Senator Campbell wanted them to voice them. Of course, in negotiating with him about it, I acknowledged that, while it might be less than a balanced outcome as far as the list of witnesses was concerned, those who had some objection or some suggestions to make—however one wants to put it—should be given some priority.

PARA.TAB: I did not want to have the trouble and expense of inviting a representative from every land council around the country who was supportive of the bill to just put that on the record. It was already known that they were supportive of the bill. The intent was to ensure that others had some access to the committee to put their views on the record. That is why there was only one supportive land council amongst those giving evidence to the committee, whereas there were several people who had objections.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there were also witnesses from ATSIC.

—I will come to that in a minute. The suggested witnesses from Senator Campbell were Robert Bropho from the Swan Valley Noongah Community Group and Dickey Cox from the Kimberley Aboriginal Association. It was known by everyone that they wanted to put contrary views to those which would have been put by just about every land council around the country, and to put on record their claim that they had not been consulted, even though there was full consultation and open information. The only other suggestion that came for witnesses was from Senator Chamarette for a representative of the New South Wales Land Council to appear because they had a different model that they wanted to propose.

PARA.TAB: I think it is absolutely ridiculous to suggest that I decided to invite witnesses. I did not decide to invite witnesses; Senator Campbell and I agreed as to which witnesses there should be. To suggest that they were based on being a biased group just makes me regret that I came to that agreement in the first place. If we wanted an overall response based on all the Aboriginal groups that there were around the country, we could have had a team of thousands. Of course, there was agreement between us that it should be limited to save committee time, to save people trouble and expense in having a whole string of people. It was agreed, in order to ensure that the contrary views were adequately represented, that that would be covered by those alternative witnesses that were suggested. I wish to place on record my rejection of the unreasonable, to say the very least, comment by the opposition members of the committee.
I would like to deal quickly with the other matter in that section of the opposition's dissenting report. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is useful to note that the ATSIC representative, after just one witness opposed the Bill, decided to withdraw from the table and refused to answer criticism of the Bill or ATSIC's role in consultation on the Bill.

What actually happened was that I had suggested that the ATSIC representatives might like to remain at the table in case issues arose during the questioning of the other witnesses which they might like to deal with. It was entirely my suggestion and, on reflection, it was probably inappropriate. I had not consulted with the ATSIC representatives before I had made that suggestion, and obviously I should have. The situation was that they wanted to be regarded as witnesses, not as just other assistants of the minister and the department. It was a question of protocol—that is all: they saw themselves not as just other officials assisting the minister but as giving their opinion as a distinct set of witnesses, as were the other witnesses. It was just a question of protocol: they saw that it emphasised their status as witnesses not to remain at the table.

PARA.TAB: As to this question of refusing to answer criticism of the bill or ATSIC's role in consultation on the bill, as I made clear at the time and as could have happened at any committee member's suggestion, those ATSIC representatives could have been requested to return to the table and give evidence and answer other questions later in the day, as I had foreshadowed early in the piece in any case.

There was no refusal on their part, merely an indication that they should be at the table only when called to give evidence rather than just be seen as assisting the minister and the representatives of the department. Any committee member could have asked for them to return if there were any further questions to be asked of them. No such request or suggestion was made. I think it is a bit rich to then say that they refused to answer criticism of the bill or of ATSIC's role in consultation on the bill.

I thought it important to put on the record the correction of those particularly niggling comments in the opposition's minority report. It is a side issue. I am not suggesting that it ought to be the central focus of this debate because it ought to be about the importance of getting the land fund up and running.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues on this bill, which is known as the indigenous land bill. The main purpose of this bill is to establish a fund which Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders can access for the purpose of purchasing land. The beneficiaries will be those who do not benefit from the Native Title Bill. That is a very hard definition to accept.

PARA.TAB: Any fund must have a fund manager. So we are establishing an indigenous land corporation to provide management for the acquisition of such land. It will be accessed by those who are dispossessed. I presume the ones that are dispossessed the most are the ones that are living in the big regional centres and cities and may not want to access land or even go back to the tribal lands of their forefathers. We are going to establish this land management by amending section 201 of the Native Title Act that we passed last year. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in his second reading speech, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult for non-indigenous Australians to understand what Australia's indigenous people feel about the loss of their land.

I presume Mr Keating was saying that the Aborigines have not got access to any land, or minimal access to land, at this stage. So I will give a few figures from my own state of Western Australia. In Western Australia land held in various forms, but not including pastoral land that was bought by ATSIC and not including freehold land bought for Aboriginal organisations, totals 27.1 million hectares; in other words, 271,000 square kilometres.

PARA.TAB: As you know, being a senator from Victoria, Madam Acting Deputy President, the size of Victoria is 227,000 square kilometres. Tasmania is 67,000 square kilometres. That means that the 271,000 square kilometres of land held by Aboriginal organisations in Western Australia—not including ATSIC pastoral areas, let me reiterate—is four times the size of Tasmania. The total area of Victoria and Tasmania is 294,600 square kilometres. So the land held by Western Australian Aboriginals is only 23,600 square kilometres short of the landmass of Victoria and Tasmania.

Do not let the Prime Minister tell anybody that the Aboriginals are devoid of land in Australia. The Aboriginals of Western Australia have more land than the size of Victoria. Their area is half the size of France—and France has 543,965 square kilometres. So in Western Australia alone they have land half the size of France and more than the size of the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland which have 244,755 square kilometres. I again remind government senators that that is only the Aboriginals of Western Australia. They have land nine times the size of Belgium, which has 30,520 square kilometres. Their land is more than twice the size of Greece. Someone might know the population of Greece. If not, Senator Bolkus would be able to tell us. He could give us a good idea, just as I could give a good idea of the population of Italy—in case someone thinks I am being racist. As I said, Aboriginals have land that amounts to more than twice the size of Greece, which has 151,985 square kilometres.

The Aboriginal population of Western Australia at the last available census was 41,779. When Mr Keating says that the Aboriginals of Australia—and I have pointed out the case in Western Australian—are without ground, it shows that he has as much grip on this situation as he has on most other portfolios around the place, especially economic portfolios. Of course, all these things exclude the massive number of hectares tied up in pastoral stations that have been bought by ATSIC. Unfortunately, they have been mismanaged by the people whom ATSIC has put in place. I do not decry the effort of buying pastoral land on behalf of Aboriginals, provided the improvements are kept up and the Aboriginals at least try to run it as an economic unit. Otherwise, the great pastoral industry of Western Australia and, indeed, all of Australia will be in jeopardy.

What is being done with the land that is already theirs? I am not talking about the land they may want to buy. In many cases they are doing nothing. I know one good farm holding—I am not talking about a pastoral holding—on agricultural land along the Moore River in Western Australia. Western Australians may remember that area as the Moore River Mission or the Magumba Mission of years gone by. It is a top-class farming area with high rainfall on the north of the Moore River.

From what I can see there, that land can run upwards of 10,000 sheep. It could take cropping. There is a lot of housing there: a lot of workshops, shearing sheds and so on. On the last visit I made to the place I found the Aboriginal population to be nil. I visit it quite often because I lease a farm on a long-term basis—I have for the last 15 years—straight opposite them on the river. There was only white management—a white manager and others working the place. I suppose they are working the place on behalf of Aboriginals. It seems to be an economic unit so some finance may flow into other things that help the Aboriginals.

But this is not the Pilbara, the Eastern Goldfields, the Murchison or the Kimberleys. It is no more than approximately 150 kilometres out of Perth. There is the odd Aboriginal there, mostly on the weekend, on shooting expeditions. Magumba was supposed to be set up as a training centre to train young Aborigines to work and manage their own land; but something has gone mighty wrong because there are never any Aboriginals there. A lot of the infrastructure is breaking down.

What is this bill about? It is about getting more land for Aboriginals. I have shown the Senate what has happened just in one place—and there are plenty of others. Some of the pastoral stations of the Kimberleys have been run pretty well by Aboriginals. By the same token, some are a disgrace. One is the Strelley group at Port Hedland which I have mentioned in this place before. It is a disgrace. The government should have an inquiry into what has been done there and into the money that has been wasted and creamed off by the white Aboriginal industry around it.

This bill is to set up a fund to get more land for Aborigines. I presume that it is for a lot of those Aborigines who are city based. A lot of them are doing pretty well in white society. I presume it is for those people in the big regional centres. Has anyone really asked the main Aboriginal population whether they want this sort of help—this ground? My rhetorical question seems to have created amusement in the advisers box, but I will continue. Has anyone asked them? As Senator McMullan may know, the white population is drifting out of the remote areas of Australia into the cities. Is the Aboriginal population going to be any different? Are the Aborigines drifting the other way?

I know a lot of Aborigines. I count quite a few Aboriginal families in Western Australia as my friends—and they have been since school days. I will not go into that right now. Are they going to change the trend of Australia's urbanisation—heading towards the coast? I do not think they are. I believe there is enough land in the bush and remote areas for them to use already. The purpose in buying the land is to provide community land. It is not freehold for individuals. Senator Murphy is looking at me.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the relevance of that?

—There is a lot of relevance. If I have ground in my name I look after it. If it is owned by 100 people it tends to get neglected. That is about how it would go. There are a lot of community based assets owned by white people in Australia. There are a lot of sporting facilities erected and paid for by the community. They are abused instead of being used properly.
—There are a lot of farmers who cannot run a chook raffle—
—Senator Murphy is entitled to look over my farm any time.
—There are plenty around that might not—and you would agree.

—Senator Murphy should judge me on my farm and not anyone else's. There should be freehold land made available to individuals who know how to handle assets and ground. Then they will take more responsibility. What happens if they do go out to the more isolated areas? It creates problems similar to those that have already been created. An example is the lack of drinking water, as Senator Ellison has already pointed out. What is the use of setting up a community where there is little or no drinking water? It creates sewerage and health problems in very tough country. I have questioned enough the management of the land they have acquired. I believe that these funds should be going into health, housing and education. Those opposite will tell us they are doing enough already.
—They're not.
—I know they are throwing money at them. Some $1.3 billion a year goes into ATSIC. There are other portfolios that come up with about $2 billion to $2.4 billion.
—Why don't they help with the grog problem?

—That is a point; I believe that would come under health. But the government has thrown money at other things under health. There are doctors in even very remote areas like Fitzroy Crossing and Halls Creek; they have more doctors than wheat belt towns have. But that does not seem to be working and the health of people in those areas is not improving. A report—its release is around the corner—supposedly on AIDS amongst Aboriginals in Western Australia, shows that health is going backwards and not forwards. Health plus education plus housing is the best way to help not only Aborigines, but anyone, including Italians, Greeks, Croatians and Macedonians who have come to Australia from overseas. That is the way to help them.

PARA.TAB: As I have already said, there are doctors on the edge of the city of Perth, for instance, who work for free to help Aborigines, especially Aboriginal children. But we have to educate Aborigines as to what doctors are doing so that they will access them. What is the point of bringing a child to a doctor when the child is nearly dead? That is where education has to get through. There was one famous—or infamous—case in Western Australia where a mother brought a child to a doctor when the child was almost dead. The doctor quickly administered drugs and asked why she had not brought it in earlier. The child picked up for a week and then unfortunately died. Aborigines have to be educated to bring in sick children earlier if the facilities are there. That is where education comes in. Australian doctors are doing something towards helping, but Aborigines have to be taught to access them.

Money is going into education to try to educate Aborigines to become professionals. I know the University of Newcastle has a quota for Aboriginal medical students and Murdoch University in Western Australia has five places set aside for Aboriginal veterinary students; they are given considerations and concessions to get them through. The way to go is to get them educated. If Aborigines want to live in good houses, houses that fit their needs—because they seem to want to live differently from the rest of Australia—then they should design housing. On my farm I do not build the sort of house that would be built in Dalkeith—even if I had the sort of money needed to build a house in Dalkeith—I build a house that suits the farm. That is what the advisers, the architects and the developers should be doing with houses for Aboriginals.

I say again that the Aboriginals this legislation should benefit the most are the city based Aboriginals who have been dispossessed, and it will urge them to go back. What is being done? Nothing in this bill says where this land will be bought, but there is plenty in and around it which says it will be community based and country sort of land. I do not think that will work in any way whatsoever because it will create more problems. If we can improve Aboriginals' health, housing and education, they will make their own decisions in due course.

I live where I live because I find it economical to do so and I find it to be a good lifestyle, but picking up people who are already city based, even though this land and money are available, will only create further problems. I believe that any money that is spent from this land fund should start with those basics, and the benefits will flow on. We will not fix this problem in two ups. It has taken 200 years to get where we are now. I believe it will take at least another 30 years of education so that they can sort out their own future. That is what we have to work at. We will not do it by throwing money at organisations which are not accountable, and where a lot of it is creamed off into the white Aboriginal society which has grown up.

My time has nearly run out. I will be speaking at the committee stage and supporting the various amendments that I and my colleagues will be moving. I look forward to the rest of the debate to see what even government speakers have to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a brief contribution to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. I have very serious reservations about the value of the package and its benefits to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, especially as it is for those who do not benefit under the Mabo legislation. The motives of some politicians and some Aboriginal leaders also worry me. It appears to be just another chapter in saying, `Here's some more money.' Money is not the answer. It never has been and never will be. The fact that this expensive package is dressed up in land does not convince me that the health, welfare and prospects of Aboriginal Australians will improve. I am worried about getting value for money. Throwing money at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people has failed dismally, actually worsening the problems in many areas.

PARA.TAB: In the 16 years from 1971 to 1986 the median age for Aboriginal school leavers increased by only 10 weeks. That is an incremental increase of only 3 1/2 school days per year. The jobless rate for Aboriginal men jumped from 6.6 per cent in 1971 to over 30 per cent in 1991. Further, Aboriginal people still earn only half the income earned by white Australians, and their life expectancy is 20 years less than that of other Australians. Child mortality for Aboriginal Australians is three times higher than the national average. Yet, despite all this, the amount of money allocated to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people has ballooned from $24 million in 1971 to $1.3 billion annually. There is more to be spent under this legislation, not on welfare but in the pursuit of justice.

The concern I have is that land in the Mabo context—which is acknowledged to benefit about only five per cent of our indigenous people—and now money in the context of this legislation, is just another attempt by this government to make itself feel good, with no convincing benefit. I do not know who can claim it but somebody is on the record as saying `Don't try and do us any more good; your attempts have done us enough harm already.' I think that is very appropriate in our attempts to meet the legitimate aspirations of many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

Our attempts to improve the prospects for them have been mixed, but the first point I wish to make is that an enormous amount of goodwill has been expended on our indigenous people. I mean that in the most generous sense. Unfortunately, this has rarely, if ever, been recognised. This probably does not wash well in the politically correct environment in which we speak, but the millions of dollars wasted, and the work of the churches and the welfare agencies, and the work of many dedicated people in the early days—like that of my late grandmother at Goodooga in the far west of New South Wales—have been motivated by people with an immense amount of goodwill. I say to Aboriginal Australians: `Recognise the efforts that have been made. It is up to you to aim for integration and partnership in this, your country.' I recognise that many Aboriginal Australians are not benefiting from the wealth of their nation, but neither are a lot of non-Aboriginal Australians.

The next point I would like to make is that I believe in one nation, one Australia. The worry I have about the Aboriginal agenda setters is that behind all of this rhetoric of getting a fair go is the creation of a separate Aboriginal landmass which would not improve the lifestyle of most Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. The preoccupation with a separate and special identity will unfortunately be to no-one's benefit in the end. I do not believe that we want this divisiveness in Australia. What is more, Australians do not deserve it, and they do not deserve to be constantly accused of being a racially intolerant society, because Australia simply is not.

It should be remembered that we are a nation of immigrants. Many of our forebears came here because they were forcibly displaced from their homes by events outside their control. It is a fact of history, mostly unfortunate, that people and peoples are overtaken by events outside their control. Such an event occurred when Europeans came to this land. From our European heritage we have formed one of the most tolerant, inclusive and decent countries of the world—with problems, certainly, but still the envy of almost all countries.

I think the happiest Aboriginal Australians are those who have taken the best that our society offers and maintained their commitment to their heritage. One has only to look at Evonne Goolagong, the Ella brothers or many Aboriginal Australians I know, to discover that happiness comes from being part of mainstream society, not standing apart from it. Complicating our system of land tenure will make helping the majority of indigenous Australians more difficult. One has only to look at the different classifications of land we now have in this country—ordinary land, which all Australians, including Aboriginals, can buy; land rights land; ATSIC land; Mabo land; and now land fund land.

Apart from the issues I have raised, the bill itself is very deceptive indeed. We were originally told that over 10 years $1.5 billion would be spent out of the budget to buy land for Aboriginal Australians. We now find that only $24 million a year extra will be spent on purchasing land, on upgrading the land they already have and on the management of that land; only a fraction of it will be spent on purchasing land.

If this government were genuine it would take on board the coalition's amendments to change the focus of the bill to address health, housing, education and economic issues. These are the issues that average Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders wants addressed. Ideology means very little to them. The government has indicated that it will also reject our amendments to address accountability. Accountability is the key to good government and also to the Aboriginal and white communities having faith in this land fund.

We must get on with the job and address issues that matter to all Australians, such as the enormous waste of talent in the 800,000 unemployed, our ballooning foreign debt and our increasing social dislocation and breakdown. The land fund, unfortunately, will not provide the dignity and respectability that I wish for Aboriginal Australians. The legislation tears at the very fabric of our egalitarian society. Now is the time for all Australians, our indigenous people and those whose forebears, like mine, came here from elsewhere, to recognise that we all belong here, that we are all Australians, that as Australians we need to help one another and that we eye the future, not punish and divide modern Australia for the wrongs done long ago—to punish ourselves, in Wordsworth's view, `for old, unhappy, far-off things and battles long ago'. Health, housing and education are the help that all of us need. They are the priorities. This package does not address those.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 will pass into legislation over the next few days—and so it should, because it is good legislation. Much has been said about the need to improve the health, housing and education of Aboriginals, together with the rest of Australians, and that is so. Efforts should be made to do just that. Senator Sandy Macdonald has said we should look to the health, education and housing of all Australians, and that is so. As he said, he is a true Australian, being the descendant of people who came from across the seas to help make this country what it is. That is, of course, true. All should be done that can be done for all Australians because we are a community.

PARA.TAB: We do different things for different sections of the community. Recently, we all joined together to pass legislation to help those affected by the drought, and so we should, because they are our brothers and sisters in the country, they are in desperate straits and we need to help them. We put money aside to help Australia be a successful multicultural country, and it is. Australia's multicultural society is one of the envies of the world and we have put money into doing that. Of course, just putting money into things does not necessarily mean that problems will be solved, but unless money is put into things, problems will not be solved.

Senator Ellison, in one of his usual, well-thought-out and cogent addresses to this chamber, said he thought it would have been better had this bill that is presently before us been put into the Mabo bill so that it became part of the Mabo bill, rather than being put into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is where it was. You are actually amending the Native Title Act and taking it back out again.
—We are putting it into this act.
—You are actually doing the first amendment to the Native Title Act, deleting section 201, taking it out again.

—Yes, but what we are doing is putting it into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act. I think what Senator Ellison was saying was that it would be better to leave it where it was, in the Mabo bill.
—It was crucial in December and expendable in October.

—That is not so. What we did in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act which we passed in 1989 was to introduce legislation with a preamble which I will take a few minutes to read because, Mr Acting Deputy President, the sorts of things I will now read would be the sorts of things that you, for example, would agree with wholeheartedly. The preamble to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 begins by stating:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation, and for related purposes.
The preamble goes on for about a page and a half. I will not read it, but I shall read part of it. It states:

PARA.TAB: WHEREAS the people of Australia voted overwhelmingly to amend the Constitution so that the Parliament of Australia would be able to make special laws for peoples of the aboriginal race;

SPEECH.PARA: You would remember that, Mr Acting Deputy President; you and I were both somewhat younger but no less wise than we are now. That was a great achievement in Australian history. It continues:

PARA.TAB: AND WHEREAS the people whose descendants are now known as Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders were the inhabitants of Australia before European settlement;

SPEECH.PARA: We set that out in this act which was passed by this parliament and was welcomed by all Australians. We put that into that particular legislation and nobody has ever attempted to take that out. The preamble continues:

PARA.TAB: AND WHEREAS they have been progressively dispossessed of their lands and this dispossession occurred largely without compensation, and successive governments have failed to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders concerning the use of their lands;

AND WHEREAS it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision for rectification, by such measures as are agreed by the Parliament from time to time, including the measures referred to in this Act, of the consequences of past injustices and to ensure that Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders receive that full recognition within the Australian nation to which history, their prior rights and interests, and their rich and diverse culture, fully entitle them to aspire;

SPEECH.PARA: I have looked at the amendments put forward today but I have seen none that in any way tries to modify or abolish the preamble to the ATSIC Act, to which the present bill will be an amendment. There is no evidence for repealing that particular preamble. I take it from that that everybody in this chamber is agreeable to the sorts of sentiments set out in that preamble. If we are all in agreement with the preamble to the ATSIC Act, the present bill fits very properly into that act, and the sorts of things it seeks to obtain are the sorts of things that should properly be obtained in conformity with that preamble.

PARA.TAB: May I say in passing that the ATSIC plan is a monument to the former minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. He laboured long and hard to get this particular legislation up. It is a pity that he has left the parliament but this is one of his great achievements. He was a great parliamentarian and a great minister, and I am glad that his efforts still have ramifications today. What we are doing today and will do over the next few days will add to his efforts.

Of course, his ideas needed a lot of honing and many people in this chamber and in the other place had much to do with that. Indeed, Mr Acting Deputy President, you made great contributions to the present situation. So it is proper that we should be debating the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 because it is simply the next step, not the final one.

Senator Woodley is to follow me in this debate and it will be interesting to hear what he has to say. No doubt he will put on his usual grand performance and will be in complete agreement with this bill. It is a good bill and it seeks to achieve great things. As I said at the start of my address, this bill deserves to be passed.

Some honourable senators have come into the chamber and conscientiously expressed their concerns about this bill. Senator Sandy Macdonald said, `We want one nation. We will not improve the situation for Aboriginals with what this bill is trying to do.' One of the problems with a bill like this is that some people think that the measures contained within it are all that will be done for Aboriginals or for Australians as a whole. That is not so. The measures contained in this bill form part of a whole network of measures that this parliament and the people of Australia have taken to make all Australians more tolerant, more generous and more religious—religious in the sense that Aboriginals pursue religion in the same way that non-Aboriginal Australians pursue religion. I close by again commending this legislation. It will be very pleasing to see it pass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, it is amazing what one speaks on these days. I rise to speak on the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994. This bill is yet another example of the deregulation we `had to have'. It is a solution to a problem which the Australian Democrats believe does not exist.
—Why are you trying to change it then?

—Senator Murphy should not interrupt; he might learn something, as I am learning as I read this speech. The fact that Australia Post is widely seen as a high-performing company which delivers a world-class service seems to be totally irrelevant. The Industry Commission has decreed that there must be more competition, and so there will be. That is not to say that the Australian Democrats are opposed to competition which is aimed at increasing efficiency, improving customer service and restraining price rises. However, our concern is that Australians expect a letter service which is accessible to everyone on an equitable basis. That is why the standard letter service is nominated as a community service obligation in the act.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators are aware, Australia Post's community service obligation can only be met by requiring urban Australians to cross-subsidise the postal services for rural and remote areas. I do not accept the common wisdom which seems to suggest that these days cross-subsidisation is a dirty word. At present, the cross-subsidy is funded by reserving a slab of postal services to Australia Post to give it enough revenue to provide a low cost standard letter service to all. That approach has been continued with this bill.

In fairness to the Industry Commission, it must be said that its report on postal services accepts the need for community service obligations. Indeed, it argues that the community service obligations to remote areas should be strengthened to guarantee everyone two deliveries per week. The Democrats endorse that recommendation and believe that it is probably the most important one made by the commission.

Where we part company from the commission is over how community service obligations should be funded. As a matter of principle, the commission believes that community service obligations should be funded by the taxpayer from consolidated revenue. This would set the scene for its preferred option of full competition in the supply of postal services. The Democrats take the view that if it is not broken, do not try to fix it. Australia Post is not perfect, but it is widely seen as a high-performing public utility. Efficiency and customer service have improved markedly in recent years and prices have been kept down. SPEECH.PARA: Your comments and requests have been examined in detail and the following changes made to the document:
One of the changes is:
The words "with limited tidal and weather access" have been added to the end of the sentence `there is a jetty at Cardwell'.

Elimination of the necessity for dredging the jetty channel will offset any negative impact caused by dredging the proposed marina channel.

A new sentence has been inserted to follow the first sentence, as follows: "Stormwater and irrigation effluent may also impact on marina water quality and the Hinchinbrook Channel.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 July 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What type of `effective writing course' and `effective business writing course' were purchased from the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, at a cost of $2 630 each.
(2) What connection does this course have with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) Effective Business Writing Course purchased at a cost of $20 813.40 through Champagne Consultants, Mona Vale, NSW.
(3) How many courses have been purchased from the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology.
(4) How many of the 500 copies of the ATO Effective Business Writing Course have been utilised since the commencement in late August/early September 1993.
(5) Have other effective business writing courses been purchased by the ATO; if so, what are their particular attributes.
(6) Why has the ATO changed course providers after outlaying over $20 000 in 1993 for an effective business writing course.
(7) What has happened to the courses that have not been used, and have they been returned; if so, has a refund been received.
(8) How many staff have now attended effective business writing courses, of either type, and has there been any notable improvement in the writing ability of these staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The `effective writing course' and `effective business writing course' are modules of the course called the `ATO Effective Business Writing Course'.
The ATO Effective Business Writing Course consists of two modules. The correct names for these modules are the:
(a) Business Writing module; and
(b) Advanced Business Writing module.

The ATO Effective Business Writing Course is a course of study developed by the ATO and an accredited delivering body, such as a TAFE or university, to meet the business writing needs of an ATO Branch office(s).

In delivering this course of study, the delivering body offers course participants the opportunity to gain a recognised accredited `Statement of Attainment' that they can use to seek entry to or exemption from other courses of study Australia-wide.
(2) The `Effective Business Writing Course' purchased from Champagne Consultants consists of a writing workbook (text) customised to meet ATO requirements.
The `ATO Effective Business Writing' workbook, is the workbook used by the participants in the ATO Effective Business Writing Course.
(3) Up to the time of this reply, the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) has conducted eight ATO Effective Business Writing courses in the five ATO Branch offices in the Melbourne region.
Of these eight courses, the course modules have been run concurrently and there have been eight Business Writing modules and five Advanced Business Writing modules.
(4) Up to the time of this reply, 334 `ATO Effective Business Writing' workbooks have been used.
Of that number, 148 workbooks have been used by course participants undertaking the `ATO Effective Business Writing Course' run by the RMIT for ATO Branch offices in the Melbourne region.

(5) No. I am unaware of any writing courses of the same magnitude being purchased. However, there may be individual components of other training courses which include some effective writing principles and practices.
(6) The ATO has not changed course providers (please see response to part (2)).
(7) The unused workbooks have not been returned for a refund; they will be used by other participants undertaking the ATO Effective Business Writing Course (please see response to part (2)).
(8) Up to the time of this reply, twelve Branch offices have run the `ATO Effective Business Writing Course'. It is anticipated another three Branch offices will run the course this year.
Of the 12 Branch offices that have run the `ATO Effective Business Writing Course':
387 ATO officers enrolled in the course;
329 ATO officers successfully completed a module or modules of the course;
3 ATO officers did not successfully complete the module in which they were enrolled; and
55 ATO officers withdrew from the course because of illness and/or work commitments.

On entry to the `ATO Effective Business Writing Course', course participants have their writing skills assessed against the terminal competencies of the Business Writing module of the course. Those participants who demonstrate a level of competency which, in the opinion of the delivering body, satisfies the Business Writing module terminal competencies, are given credit for the Business Writing module and given entry to the Advanced Business Writing module (Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL)).
As part of the course work, each participant completes a number of work-related assessment tasks. These tasks are set and assessed by the delivering body so as to monitor a participant's progress.

ATO officers who satisfy the course requirements and who are judged by the delivering body to have achieved the terminal competencies of either the Business Writing module or the Advanced Business Writing module, are awarded a `Statement of Attainment'. Those officers who have successfully complete a module or modules of the `ATO Effective Business Writing Course' have been assessed as being competent in business writing skills.
