TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) When did the Government decide the exact terms of the new rate for the Jobstart subsidy.

(2) Why were the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) offices around Australia not advised of the exact changes to the Jobstart Program outlined in the Government's White Paper on employment in time to provide proper advice to their clients.

(3) Is the Minister aware that many CES clients hold Cards deemed to be valid for 3 months which were issued just prior to the legislative change and which advise potential employers of a Jobstart subsidy of $200 for 16 weeks instead of the new rate of $100 for 13 weeks.
(4) Can these cards be honoured.
(5) Did the Department make any attempt to formally notify its clients that their cards were not valid and that the new rates had come into effect.

(6) In cases where a client presented a Jobstart card to a potential employer without knowledge of the new rate and the employer agreed to employ that person on the basis of the old subsidy rate, can exemptions be made for the card holder from the new lower rate.
(7) Given the downward trend in employment opportunities for young Australians aged 15 to 19, what impact will the reduction of the Jobstart subsidy have on this age group.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Revised Jobstart subsidy rates and durations were announced on 4 May 1994 in the Government's Working Nation White Paper. The Government substantially increased subsidies for those out of work the longest and reduced rates for those out of work for shorter periods. These changes recognise that in periods of economic recovery, those out of work for short periods need less assistance to return to work while additional assistance is required to ensure that the long term unemployed are able to compete for jobs.

(2) All CES offices were advised about the exact changes to the Jobstart subsidy rates and durations immediately following the release of Working Nation on 4 May 1994. The new Jobstart rates came into effect on 4 July 1994. Up to this time the previous rates remained current.
(3) There were no legislative changes associated with the variations in Jobstart subsidies which came into effect on 4 July 1994.

Jobstart Self Canvassing Cards are issued to eligible jobseekers to assist them in getting a job. The Cards inform potential employers that a wage subsidy may be available. It does not commit the Commonwealth to a particular level of subsidy. Cards are issued for a three month period and identify the rates and durations of subsidy which apply at the time Cards are issued. The actual rates that would be payable when a jobseeker finds employment may vary from that shown on the card for a number of reasons (including, for example, when a person moves to a higher rate of subsidy). Therefore, the Cards clearly identify that the employer must contact the CES to confirm eligibility for a subsidy.

(4) Jobstart Self Canvassing Cards are an aid which jobseekers can use to assist themselves in securing employment. They do not contain commitments to pay particular levels of Jobstart subsidy. The Cards clearly state that to be eligible to receive a Jobstart subsidy the employer must always contact the local CES to confirm eligibility and to complete an agreement with the CES before the jobseeker starts work.

(5) As pointed out in the answer to question three, rates of subsidy can vary from that shown on the card. Individual Cards are progressively updated during review interviews with jobseekers, when jobseekers request replacement Cards or when Cards are issued for new periods.
(6) See the answer to question 4.
(7) The changes to the rates payable for young people under Jobstart are part of a comprehensive package of assistance flowing from Working Nation.

Working Nation announced initiatives to assist young people. There are three key elements in the Government's strategy for building the skills of young people and improving their ability to compete successfully in the workforce:
encouraging young people to participate in education and training through financial support and by making schooling more relevant;
increasing the number and range of entry level training places available to young people; and
improving the employment prospects of young people through better access to training opportunities through the Youth Training Initiative.

A new system of training wages and subsidies was introduced on 5 September 1994 following the ratification of the National Training Wage Award by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The National Training Wage forms the basis for the significant expansion of training and entry level places for young Australians set out and funded through Working Nation. This Award represents a partnership approach on the part of Government, industry and the trade union movement which has the interests of the unemployed, particularly the young and long term unemployed, at its centre. The Award provides for a streamlining of the traineeship system on an industry basis with a simplified wage structure. Traineeships will be more flexible than in the past, accessible and driven by industry needs, with the red tape and inflexibility of the past being overcome.

Under the Youth Training Initiative unemployed young people aged 15 to 17 years will be case managed after thirteen weeks unemployment. If they are still unemployed after six months they will be offered an education, training or employment place.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 21 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the provision by the NSW Government of Landcom land in the NSW coastal zone for farmers desperately needing agistment for starving, irreplaceable breeding stock, will any suitable tracts of Comrnonwealth-owned land be provided for the same stock agistment purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The management of some Commonwealth properties has been devolved to occupant departments, such as the Department of Defence or to Government Business Enterprises such as the Federal Airports Corporation. Therefore, at present, there is no central coordinating agency able to give a decision on all Commonwealth properties in relation to this issue.

In practice under a devolved management system, farmers seeking access to Commonwealth-owned land for stock agistment purposes would usually contact the relevant occupying government agency directly through their respective regional administration offices.

The normal approach taken to the management of broadacre sites, such as Defence bases and major airports, which may have substantial grassed areas on the property is to put in place either a grazing licence or a grass cutting contract. This is part of ongoing maintenance of such properties and is essential to reduce the risk of fire.

On major Defence bases, a grazing licence is usually the best option as it ensures the fire risk is reduced and also generates a small amount of revenue for the Commonwealth. Where grazing licences are in place, availability of the land for grazing by other than the licensed grazier would naturally be reduced or precluded entirely. Approaches for emergency agistment measures would be treated on a case by case basis taking Defence needs and land management requirements into account.

On properties such as airports, or properties contiguous to airports, management would usually arrange a grasscutting contract, since the presence of grazing animals could contribute to an increased bird presence and a consequential increased likelihood of bird strikes on aeroplanes. Such contracts nommally allow for the grasscutter to cut and bale the grass and sell up to a specified limit to cover his costs. Baled grass over and above that limit may be sold on behalf of the Commonwealth, although, in the past it has been donated to drought affected areas. A recent example of this was grass baled at the former Brisbane Airport and Floodway area being transported to drought affected areas.

I expect that Commonwealth Government agencies would be well aware of the difficulties facing drought affected fammers at present and stand willing to assist where they can. For example, within the Administrative Services portfolio, Australian Estate Management Regional Managers have been instructed to look at the opportunities in their regions to help drought affected farmers by donating grass or by making properties available for grazing.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Energy Efficient Audit Program (EEAP) within the department:
(1) Is the Minister aware of the success rate of this program in relation to the number of companies that have implemented the recommendations from these energy audits.
(2) Does the department have a follow-up program to ascertain the effectiveness of the program.
(3) Is any scheme being considered to assist companies to implement the recommendations from these EEAP audits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. Recipients of support under the Enterprise Energy Audit Program (EEAP) are requested to complete a questionnaire on implementation of audit recommendations approximately 12 months after the completion of the audits. Responses are analysed to assist in assessing effectiveness. Based on some 550 audit reports under EEAP, about 25% of enterprises have implemented some or all of the audit recommendations, or are in the process of implementing them. A further 40% are giving consideration to audit recommendations.

(3) Beyond EEAP, the department currently supports the adoption of energy efficiency improvements in industry and commerce through a program of studies in selected industries and the dissemination of relevant educational information. In addition, the department utilises the National Industry Extension Service to promote EEAP including the adoption of audit recommendations. A study for the Australian and New Zealand Minerals and Energy Council of energy auditing and energy management training programs is nearing completion and will provide a basis for further consideration of possible measures to assist industry and commerce in these areas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Guidelines for the provision of government legal services

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz has a question on notice. I ask leave to incorporate in Hansard the answer to question No. 1709, for which Senator Abetz is waiting. There is an accompanying document, Guidelines for the provision of government legal services, which I table.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

In February 1991 the Government decided to introduce a system of user pays for the provision of legal services to departments and Budget-dependent agencies. Briefly; the system approved at that time provided that departments and Budget-dependent agencies were required, subject to a review in 1994, to continue to obtain their externally sourced legal services from the Attorney-General's Department until 30 June 1995. After that date a range of those services would be opened up to competition from private sector service providers.

The 1994 review has since been carried out and the Government has decided to maintain the 1991 decision to tie departments and Budget-dependent agencies' legal services to the Attorney-General's Department until 30 June 1995.

In the course of reaching the 1991 decision the Government endorsed certain principles of the user pays system which were set out in the Guidelines for the Provision of Government Legal Services. A copy of the Guidelines is attached.

Amongst those principles was provision for a service agreement to be entered into between the Attorney-General's Department and each department and Budget-dependent agency describing the legal services to be provided and regulating the provision of those services. Paragraphs nine and ten refer.
I am advised that a number of departments and Budget-dependent agencies have concluded service agreements with the Attorney-General's Department.

In respect of the arrangements between the Legal Practice and the Department of Defence and other Commonwealth departments and agencies in relation to the exclusive provision of legal services I am advised that no authorisation has been sought from the Trade Practices Commission because it is considered that the Trade Practices Act 1974 has no application to those arrangements because they are, in effect, internal administrative arrangements for the provision by the Commonwealth of legal services to other emanations of the Commonwealth.
